Sebbene fosse un governatore serio e riflessivo a casa, Luigi aveva un grande desiderio di "gloria" internazionale, che per lui significava la vittoria sul campo di battaglia. Era sempre in lotta con i suoi vicini, spesso per le ragioni più futili, nonostante questi scontri gli portassero soltanto la gloria. Al termine del suo regno, lasciò l'esercito e la flotta navale in ottime condizioni, ma, al tempo stesso, prosciugò la tesoreria nazionale.[PARAGRAPH:2]Luigi XIV morì dopo aver governato la Francia per 72 anni.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Luis XIV[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Rey de Francia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió:[\BOLD] 1643 - 1715 d. C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biografía:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Hijo de Luis XIII de Francia, Luis XIV se crió en la corte más opulenta de Europa. Todas sus necesidades estaban cubiertas y recibió una excelente educación, aunque fuera demasiado perezoso y mimado para apreciarla. Luis XIII murió cuando su hijo tenía cinco años, y la regencia recayó en las manos de la reina madre, Ana de Austria. Durante los dieciocho años siguientes, Ana gobernó con la ayuda del cardenal Mazarino (quien tal vez fuese también su amante), mientras Luis vivía envuelto en un exceso de esplendor.[PARAGRAPH:2]Fue a la muerte de Mazarino, en 1661, cuando Luis XIV, a la sazón un joven de 22 años, empezó a interesarse más activamente por el gobierno de su país. Para sorpresa generalizada, demostró grandes aptitudes. Para empezar, reunió todo el poder en sus propias manos, desmontando el anticuado sistema de patronazgo burocrático empleado por Mazarino y sus predecesores. Reunió a todos los nobles importantes en su corte, donde los colmó de títulos, honores y recompensas económicas, al mismo tiempo que minaba su poder real. En la corte de Luis, los grandes nobles, cuyos antecesores habían luchado por la Corona de Francia, peleaban por el derecho a presenciar el afeitado del rey.[PARAGRAPH:2]Según parece, en persona Luis poseía gran dignidad y un porte regio. Siempre se mostraba cortés, y normalmente honesto, pero en caso necesario podía ser tan sibilino como el que más.[PARAGRAPH:2]Durante los primeros años de su reinado, su corte se hizo famosa por su depravación, y el propio Luis tuvo varias amantes. Sin embargo, a medida que avanzaba el tiempo, la piedad del rey fue en aumento, e incluso llegó a casarse con su última amante (aunque en secreto). También fue un mecenas de las artes, y bajo su reinado florecieron la literatura y la pintura. Construyó muchos grandes edificios y palacios, incluido el enorme complejo palacial de Versalles.[PARAGRAPH:2]A pesar de la riqueza de Francia, el país se mantenía virtualmente en estado de bancarrota, no solo porque hubiera que pagar los regalos que Luis hacía a sus favoritos, sino, y mucho más importante, por la necesidad de costear las guerras de conquista en las que se embarcaba. Aunque desde el punto de vista interno era un gobernante razonable y sensato, Luis tenía una inagotable sed de "gloria" internacional... lo que, desde su punto de vista, significaba victorias en el campo de batalla. Constantemente se enfrentaba a sus vecinos, a menudo por las más triviales de las razones sin que estas guerras proporcionaran gran cosa al país, aparte de gloria. Dejó el ejército y la marina en magníficas condiciones, pero a costa de agotar los cofres del reino.[PARAGRAPH:2]Luis XIV murió tras setenta y dos años de reinado.

TEXT.English: [H1]Musa I[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Mansa of Mali[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c.1280 - 1337 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Musa was the grandson of Sundiata Keita, the Muslim founder of the Mali Empire, which existed on the Mandinka plateau in West Africa from the 14th to the 17th centuries. At the time Mali was the source of over half of the world's gold, and Musa was fabulously wealthy. During his famous hajj (pilgrimage to Mecca) in 1324, Musa gave away so much gold in Cairo that the price of gold there was depressed for the next twenty years. He gave away so much treasure, in fact, that he had to borrow money to pay for his return trip. Legend has it that Musa was accompanied on his journey by a huge retinue and honor guard, not to mention 60,000 porters to carry the supplies.[PARAGRAPH:2]Called "Musa the Magnificent," Mansa was celebrated for his enlightenment and piety. He added the important towns of Timbuktu and Gao to his kingdom. Upon reaching the throne, Musa became a feverish Muslim, and he built countless mosques across the country and made Islam the state religion, though he did not persecute other religions in his country.[PARAGRAPH:2]Musa encouraged trade between Mali and the world beyond, using his country's vast resources of kola nuts, ivory, salt, and gold to attain goods from three continents. A believer in knowledge, Musa made the city of Timbuktu into a center of learning and craftsmanship, and Sankore University was one of the great schools in the Muslim world. Students came from all over to receive a free education there.[PARAGRAPH:2]Musa died in 1337, after ruling Mali for twenty-five years. A contemporary historian said of Masa Musa, that, of all of the leaders in West Africa, he was, "the most powerful, the richest, the most fortunate, and the most feared by his enemies and the most able to do good for those around him."
TEXT.French: [H1]Kankan Moussa[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Souverain de l'empire du Mali[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates:[\BOLD] vers 1280 - 1337 ap. J.-C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biographie:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Moussa est le petit-fils de Soundiata Keita, le fondateur musulman de l'empire du Mali qui s'étend sur le plateau du Mandé en Afrique de l'Ouest, du XIVe au XVIIe siècle. A cette époque, le Mali fournit plus de la moitié de l'or du monde et Moussa se trouve à la tête d'une extraordinaire fortune. Au cours de son célèbre pèlerinage à La Mecque en 1324, Moussa dépense tant de dinars d'or au Caire que le cours de l'or y sera affaibli pour les vingt années à venir. Il dilapide à ce point son trésor qu'il se voit contraint d'emprunter de l'argent pour payer son voyage retour. Selon la légende, Moussa était accompagné pendant son voyage d'une immense escorte, ainsi que d'une garde d'honneur et de 60 000 porteurs pour transporter le matériel et le ravitaillement.[PARAGRAPH:2]Appelé "Moussa le Magnifique", Kankan est célèbre pour son érudition et sa piété. Il offre à son royaume les villes importantes de Tombouctou et de Gao. A son accession au trône, Moussa devient un fervent musulman et entreprend la construction d'innombrables mosquées dans tout le pays, faisant de l'Islam la religion d'Etat tout en acceptant la pratique d'autres cultes dans son pays.[PARAGRAPH:2]Moussa encourage les échanges commerciaux entre le Mali et le reste du monde, troquant les nombreuses ressources de son pays telles que les noix de cola, l'ivoire, le sel et l'or contre des produits originaires des trois autres continents. Croyant aux vertus de la connaissance, Moussa fait de Tombouctou un centre d'art et d'érudition, tout comme de l'université de Sankoré l'une des grandes écoles du monde musulman. Des étudiants du monde entier viennent y recevoir gratuitement une éducation.[PARAGRAPH:2]Moussa meurt en 1337, après avoir régné sur le Mali pendant vingt-cinq ans. Un historien contemporain dit de Kankan Moussa que, de tous les dirigeants d'Afrique de l'Ouest, il était "le plus puissant, le plus riche, le plus fortuné, le plus craint de ses ennemis et le plus doué pour répandre le bien sur son entourage".
TEXT.German: [H1]Mansa Musa[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Herrscher über das Malireich[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Gestorben:[\BOLD] Um 1280 - 1337 n. Chr.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Musa war der Enkel Sundiata Keitas, des muslimischen Gründers des Malireichs auf dem Madinka-Plateau in Westafrika. Legendär wurde seine Pilgerfahrt nach Mekka im Jahr 1324. Der sagenhaft reiche König gab auf der Reise so viel Gold aus, dass er in Ägypten den Wert des auf Gold basierenden Dinars für etwa 20 Jahre ruinierte. Da das Gold plötzlich nicht mehr seinen ursprünglichen Wert hatte, musste sich Musa auf dem Rückweg von einem Händler sogar Geld leihen. Der Legende nach wurde Musa von einem riesigen Gefolge, seiner Ehrengarde und etwa 60.000 Trägern begleitet.[PARAGRAPH:2]Musa hatte den Beinamen "der Prächtige" und galt als kluger und frommer Herrscher. Er machte Timbuktu zu einer der bedeutendsten Städte Afrikas, baute unzählige Moscheen und erklärte den Islam zur Staatsreligion, ohne jedoch andere Religionen zu unterdrücken.[PARAGRAPH:2]Musa förderte den Handel mit anderen Ländern und tauschte Kolanüsse, Elfenbein, Salz und Gold gegen andere Waren ein. Timbuktu wurde unter Musa ein Zentrum des Wissens und des Handwerks. Die Sankore-Universität gehörte zu den größten Schulen der muslimischen Welt.[PARAGRAPH:2]Musa starb nach 25-jähriger Regentschaft im Jahr 1337. Ein zeitgenössischer Historiker sagte über Mansa Musa, dass er von allen Regenten Westafrikas "der mächtigste, reichste, glücklichste und gefürchtetste Herrscher war, der seinen Mitmenschen wie kein anderer Gutes tat."
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Mansa Musa[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Capo dell'Impero del Mali[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vissuto nel:[\BOLD] ca. 1280 - 1337 d.C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Storia:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Musa era il nipote di Sundiata Keita, il fondatore Musulmano dell'Impero del Mali, situato nella pianura Mandinka dell'Africa dell'Ovest tra il XIV e il XVII secolo. A quel tempo, il Mail era la fonte primaria di oltre metà dell'oro mondiale e Musa era incredibilmente ricco. Durante il suo famoso hajj (il pellegrinaggio alla Mecca), nel 1324, distribuì talmente tanta ricchezza nel Cairo, che il prezzo dell'oro calò drasticamente per diversi anni. In effetti, sperperò talmente tanto tesoro, che dovette prendere in prestito i soldi per pagare il viaggio di ritorno. La leggenda vuole che Musa fosse accompagnato nel suo viaggio da un'enorme seguito da e dalla guardia d'onore, oltre a 60.000 facchini per trasportare i rifornimenti.[PARAGRAPH:2]Noto anche come "Musa il Magnifico", Mansa divenne celebre per la sua saggezza e la sua pietà. Integrò le importanti città di Timbuktu e di Gao al suo regno. Una volta salito al trono, Musa divenne un Musulmano convinto e costruì innumerevoli moschee per tutto il regno, istituendo l'Islamismo come religione di stato, sebbene non perseguitò mai le altre religioni nel suo paese.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mura incoraggiò gli scambi commerciali tra il Mali e il mondo esterno, usando le vaste risorse di noci di cola, avorio, sale e oro del paese per ottenere merci dai tre continenti. Convinto sostenitore della conoscenza, Musa fece di Timbuktu il centro dell'apprendimento e delle arti: l'Università Sankore fu una delle più grandi scuole di tutto il mondo Musulmano. Qui gli studenti giungevano da ogni parte del paese per ricevere un'educazione gratuita.[PARAGRAPH:2]Musa morì nel 1337, dopo aver governato il Mali per 25 anni. Uno storico contemporaneo ha detto di Mansa Musa che, di tutti i capi dell'Africa dell'Ovest, "fu il più potente, il più ricco, il più fortunato e il più temuto dai nemici, nonché quello che si adoperò di più per il bene del popolo".
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Kankan Musa[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Líder del imperio de Malí[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió:[\BOLD] c.1280 - 1337 d. C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biografía:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Musa era nieto de Sundiata Keita, el musulmán que fundó el imperio de Malí, una entidad política que existió en la llanura Mandika de África occidental entre los siglos XIV y XVII. En aquella época, Malí era el origen de la mitad del oro del mundo, y Musa era fabulosamente rico. Durante su famoso hajj (peregrinación a La Meca) de 1324, Musa gastó tanto oro en El Cairo que el precio de este metal no se recuperaría hasta veinte años después. De hecho, su prodigalidad fue tanta que tuvo que pedir dinero prestado para costearse el viaje de regreso. Según la leyenda, contó en su viaje con un séquito inmenso y una gigantesca guardia, por no hablar de los 60.000 portadores que cargaban con los pertrechos.[PARAGRAPH:2]Llamado "Musa el magnífico," Mansa era famoso por su ilustración y piedad. Añadió los importantes pueblos de Timbuktu y Gao a su reino. Al subir al trono, se convirtió en un ferviente musulmán, y erigió incontables mezquitas por todo el país, además de convertir el Islam en la religión oficial. Sin embargo, no persiguió a las demás religiones.[PARAGRAPH:2]Musa fomentó el comercio entre Malí y el mundo exterior, usando los vastos recursos con que contaba el país (nueces de kola, marfil, sal y oro) para conseguir mercancías de los tres continentes. Devoto del conocimiento, convirtió la ciudad de Timbuktu en un centro de sabiduría y artesanía, y la universidad de Sankore pasó a ser una de las grandes escuelas del mundo musulmán. Acudían a ella estudiantes de todas partes para recibir una educación gratuita.[PARAGRAPH:2]Musa murió en 1337, tras haber gobernado Malí durante veinticinco años. Un historiador contemporáneo de Masa Musa dijo de él, que, entre todos los gobernantes del África occidental, era: "el más poderoso, el más rico, el más afortunado, el más temido por sus enemigos y el más capacitado para procurar bien a quienes lo rodean".

TEXT.English: [H1]Dona Maria II[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Queen Regent of Portugal and the Algarves[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1819 - 1853 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Dona Maria II was Queen regnant of Portugal from 1826 to 1828 and later from 1834 to 1853. She was the second Queen regnant of Portugal and the Algarves, and the 29th or 30th Portuguese monarch. She was a member of the House of Braganza.[NEWLINE]Born as Maria da Glória Joana Carlota Leopoldina da Cruz Francisca Xavier de Paula Isidora Micaela Gabriela Rafaela Gonzaga, Maria da Glória was the daughter of the future King of Portugal and first Emperor of Brazil, Peter IV and his first wife Maria Leopoldina, Archduchess of Austria, herself a daughter of Emperor Francis II. Born in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Maria is the only European monarch to not have been born in Europe.[PARAGRAPH:2]When Maria's grandfather King John VI died in March 1826, there was a succession crisis in Portugal. The king had a male heir, Peter, but Peter had proclaimed the independence of Brazil in 1822 and he was then Emperor Peter I of that country. The late king also had a younger son, Miguel, but he was exiled in Austria after leading a number of revolutions against his father and his liberal regime.[NEWLINE]Before his death, the king had nominated his favourite granddaughter, Isabel Maria, to serve as regent until "the legitimate heir returned to the Kingdom" but he had failed to specify which of his sons was the legitimate heir. Peter, the liberal Emperor of Brazil, or Miguel, the absolutist exiled prince?[PARAGRAPH:2]Most people considered Peter to be the legitimate heir, but nobody wanted him to unite Portugal and Brazil's thrones again. The European country had been under Brazilian rule when both were part of the United Kingdom of Portugal, Brazil and the Algarves, established by the King John VI during his stay in Rio de Janeiro from 1808 until 1820. Aware that his brother's supporters were ready to bring Miguel back and put him in the throne, Peter decided for a more consensual option; he abdicated the throne to his eldest daughter, Maria da Glria (who was only seven years old), and she should marry her uncle Miguel, who should accept the liberal constitution and act as a regent until his niece was an adult.[PARAGRAPH:2]Miguel pretended to accept, but when he arrived in Portugal he deposed Maria and proclaimed himself King, abrogating the liberal constitution in the process. During his reign of terror, Maria traveled to many European courts, including her grandfather's in Vienna, as well as London and Paris.[PARAGRAPH:2]Peter abdicated the Brazilian throne in 1831 in favor of his son (and Maria's younger brother, Peter II), and from his base in the Azores he attacked Miguel, forcing him to abdicate in 1834. Maria was thereupon restored to the throne, and obtained an annulment of her betrothal.[PARAGRAPH:2]On January 26, 1835 she married (at the age of fifteen) to Auguste, Duke of Leuchtenberg, son of Eugne de Beauharnais, and grandson of Empress Josephine. However, he died only two months later on March 28, 1835.[PARAGRAPH:2]On January 1, 1836 Maria married again, to the cultured and able Prince Ferdinand of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, who ruled with her as a co-monarch. He received the title of King in 1837, in accordance with Portuguese custom, upon the birth of their first child Peter, an heir to the throne.[PARAGRAPH:2]Maria's reign saw a revolutionary insurrection on May 16, 1846, but this was crushed by royalist troops on February 22, 1847, and Portugal otherwise avoided the European upheavals of 1848. Maria's reign was also notable for a public health act aimed at curbing the spread of cholera throughout the country. She also pursued policies aimed at raising the levels of education throughout the country.[PARAGRAPH:2]After constant pregnancies and births, doctors warned Maria of the dangers of giving birth nearly every year. However, she ignored the risks that had killed her mother, who had died of complications following a miscarriage after many births; "If I die, I die at my post", Maria said. In 1853 she died while giving birth to her eleventh child, Prince Eugene, who also died.[PARAGRAPH:2]Maria II is remembered as a good mother and a kind person, who always acted according to her convictions in the attempt to help her country. She was later given the surname "The Good Mother." Also, in 1842, Pope Gregory XVI presented Maria with a Golden Rose.
TEXT.German: [H1]Maria II.[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Königin von Portugal[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] 1819 - 1853 n. Chr.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Maria II. Herzogin von Porto war Knigin von Portugal von 1826 bis 1828 und von 1834 bis 1853. Sie war die letzte Herrscherin aus dem Haus Braganza.[NEWLINE]Geboren als Maria da Glria Joana Carlota Leopoldina da Cruz Francisca Xavier de Paula Isidora Micaela Gabriela Rafaela Gonzaga, war Maria die lteste Tochter von Peter IV. von Portugal und dessen erster Gemahlin Maria Leopoldine von sterreich. Ihr Vater hatte 1821 die brasilianische Unabhngigkeit erklrt und sich zum Kaiser Peter I. von Brasilien ausrufen lassen. 1826 erbte er zustzlich noch den portugiesischen Thron, den er als Peter IV. bestieg. Da es ihm nicht mglich war, beide Reiche Portugal und Brasilien gleichzeitig zu regieren, trat er schon nach wenigen Monaten als portugiesischer Knig zugunsten von Maria zurck. Diese bestieg so 1826 zum ersten Mal den portugiesischen Thron.[PARAGRAPH:2]Maria war zu diesem Zeitpunkt gerade sieben Jahre alt und regierte deshalb whrend ihrer ersten Herrschaftsperiode nur dem Namen nach. Ihr Vater hatte seinen jngeren Bruder, Prinz Michael, der sich zu diesem Zeitpunkt wegen seiner Opposition gegen eine konstitutionelle Monarchie in Portugal (Michael wollte absolutistisch regieren) gerade im Exil in Wien befand, zum Regenten fr Maria berufen, nachdem dieser die von Peter dem Land gegebene Verfassung, die Charta akzeptiert hatte. Spter htte sie ihren Onkel Michael heiraten und mit diesem gemeinsam das Land regieren sollen. In Wien wurde sogar eine Stellvertreterhochzeit gefeiert.[PARAGRAPH:2]Michael hatte allerdings andere Plne. Nachdem er nach Portugal zurckgekehrt war, setzte er die Charta auer Kraft, erklrte Maria II. fr abgesetzt und sich selbst zum Knig. Maria verlor so 1828 zunchst ihren Thron.[PARAGRAPH:2]Peter war nicht bereit, diesen Vertrauensbruch seines Bruders hinzunehmen. Er dankte 1831 auch als Herrscher von Brasilien ab, ging nach Europa, um dort den Kampf gegen seinen Bruder und fr den Thron seiner Tochter aufzunehmen. Es begann der Miguelistenkrieg, der 1834 mit einer Niederlage Michaels endete. Maria, seit 1833 Herzogin von Porto, wurde dadurch erneut Knigin, kurze Zeit spter starb ihr Vater, sie wurde von den Cortes fr volljhrig erklrt und begann selbstndig zu regieren.[PARAGRAPH:2]Knigin Maria II. von Portugal: Die Regierungszeit Maria II. gehrt zu den bewegtesten Perioden der portugiesischen Geschichte. Die Konstitutionalisten, also die Anhnger der konstitutionellen Monarchie, hatten sich in einen rechtsliberal-konservativen (die sog. Cartisten) und einen linksliberalen Flgel (die Setembristen) gespalten. Die Regierungszeit Marias war geprgt von der Auseinandersetzung zwischen diesen beiden Gruppen, die sogar zu einem offenen Brgerkrieg fhrte. Die Knigin stand dabei auf Seiten der Cartisten, in Zeiten, in denen die Setembristen die Oberhand hatten, untersttzte sie zum Teil offen die cartistischen Krfte (siehe Belenzada).[PARAGRAPH:2]Antnio Bernardo da Costa Cabral, der Markgraf von Tomar, war whrend ihrer Regentschaft viele Jahre Ministerprsident und regierte das Land diktatorisch. Die Knigin hielt an ihm gegen groe Widerstnde im Lande fest, was das Land an den Rand eines Brgerkriegs brachte.[PARAGRAPH:2]In erster Ehe heiratete Maria 1835 August Beauharnais von Leuchtenberg (1810-1835). Dieser verstarb bereits zwei Monate nach der Eheschlieung an der Spanischen Grippe. 1836 vermhlte sie sich in zweiter Ehe mit Ferdinand II. aus dem Haus Sachsen-Coburg und Gotha. Das Wappen der portugiesischen Knige von Johann II. bis Manuel II.[PARAGRAPH:2]1853 starb die Knigin bei der Geburt ihres elften Kindes im Alter von nur 34 Jahren. Whrend ihrer Regentschaft hatte sie ein exemplarisches Familienleben mit ihrem Ehemann Ferdinand von Sachsen-Coburg und Gotha gefhrt. Die Knigin bedauerte oft, dass die politisch auergewhnlich turbulenten Zeiten ihr nicht gengend Zeit lieen, die sie ihrer Familie widmen konnte. Sie wurde als gutmtige Knigin und beispielhafte Ehefrau und Mutter von ihrem Volk verehrt, andererseits wegen ihrer konservativen Ansichten oft auch scharf kritisiert. Neben ihrem Festhalten an erzkonservativen Politikern wie Costa Cabral und Saldanha wurde besonders kritisiert, dass sie sich auch in ihrem Palast mit einer konservativen Kamarilla umgab, die die Handlungen der Knigin zum Teil sehr beeinflussten. Besonders in der Kritik stand hier der deutsche Erzieher ihrer Kinder, Dr. Dietz, den Ferdinand mit nach Portugal gebracht hatte.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mit der Regentschaft Maria II. endete in Portugal die Herrschaft des Hauses Braganza. Marias Nachfolger wurde ihr ltester Sohn, Peter V. ber ihn kam das Haus Sachsen-Coburg und Gotha in Portugal zur Macht, die letzte Dynastie, die Portugal regieren sollte.

TEXT.English: [H1]Nzinga Mbemba[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Mwene Kongo[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c.1456 - c.1542 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Mvemba a Nzinga or Nzinga Mbemba (c. 1456 - 1542 or 1543), also known as King Afonso I, was a ruler of the Kingdom of Kongo in the first half of the 16th century. He reigned over the Kongo Empire from 1509 to late 1542 or 1543.[PARAGRAPH:2]Born Mvemba a Nzinga, son of Manikongo (Mwene Kongo) (king) Nzinga a Nkuwu, the fifth king of the Kongo dynasty. At the time of the first arrival of the Portuguese to the Kingdom of the Kongo's capital of Mbanza Kongo in 1491, Mvemba a Nzinga was in his thirties, and was the ruler of the Nsundi province (on the northeast), and likely heir to the throne. He added the name Afonso when he was baptized after his father decided to convert to Christianity. and studied with Portuguese priests and advisers for ten years in the kingdom's capital. Letters written by priests to the king of Portugal paint Afonso as an enthusiastic and scholarly convert to Christianity. In around 1495, the Manikongo denounced Christianity, and Afonso welcomed the priests into the capital of his Nsundi province. To the displeasure of many in the realm, he had traditional art objects that might offend Portuguese sensibilities destroyed. Afonso's alliance with the Portuguese was rewarded when he fought conservatives for succession to the throne. The victory over his brother in the Battle of Mbanza-Kongo "was won because of aid from Portuguese weapons."[PARAGRAPH:2]Virtually all that is known about Kongo in the time of Afonso's reign is known from his long series of letters, written in Portuguese primarily to the kings Manuel I and João III of Portugal. The letters are often very long and give many details about the administration of the country. Many of the letters complain about the behavior of several Portuguese officials, and these letters have given rise to an interpretation of Afonso's reign as one in which Portuguese interests submerged Afonso's ambitions.[PARAGRAPH:2]In Adam Hochschild's 1998 book King Leopold's Ghost, Hochschild characterizes Afonso as a "selective modernizer" because he welcomed European scientific innovation and the church but refused to adopt Portugal's legal code and sell land to prospectors. In fact, Afonso ridiculed the Ordenacoes Manuelinas (new Portuguese law code) when he read them in 1516, asking the Portuguese emissary de Castro, "What is the punishment, Castro, for putting one's feet on the ground?" No contemporary record mentions anything about land sales, indeed land in Kongo was never sold to anyone.

[H1]Mehmed II the Conqueror[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan of the Ottoman Empire[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1432 - 1481 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Mehmed II, also known as el-Fatih ("the Conqueror") was the sultan of the Ottoman Empire from 1451 - 1481 AD. He is best known for capturing the city of Constantinople, turning it into the new Ottoman capital and destroying the Byzantine Empire in the process. Mehmed was born in Edirne, which was then the capital of the Ottoman state, in 1432. He was fascinated by military matters from an early age; by the time that he reached maturity and ascended to the position of sultan (in 1451), Mehmed was prepared to begin the attack upon the city of Constantinople.[PARAGRAPH:2]During the thousand-year history of the Byzantine Empire, Constantinople had withstood sieges many times. It had only been captured once, by the Fourth Crusaders in 1204. But by the fifteenth century the Byzantine Empire was a battered shell of its former self: while it still held Constantinople, it retained only a few small territories outside the cities walls (mainly in Greece).[PARAGRAPH:2]Mehmed began the siege by constructing a pair of fortresses on both sides of the straights surrounding the city, thus preventing reinforcement by sea. When Mehmed attacked in 1453, the Byzantines were horribly outnumbered: there were only 7000 defenders to meet an army of roughly 100,000 Turks. Help was not forthcoming from the West, which remained hostile to the Byzantines because of the split between the Catholic and Orthodox churches.[PARAGRAPH:2]Using enormous primitive cannon, the Ottomans battered the walls of Constantinople for weeks (although the rate of fire was so slow that the defenders were able to repair much of the damage as it took place). On May 29 Mehmed finally ordered an assault at a damaged section of the walls. The assault was successful, and the attackers succeeded in breaking into the city streets. The cities fate was sealed. The last Emperor, Constantine XI, died in battle, and the ancient empire was extinguished forever.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mehmed gave his soldiers a day to loot the city (which was a customary practice at the time), during which a large portion of the populace was slaughtered, raped, or enslaved. After his soldiers' greed and lust were sated, Mehmed made every effort to rebuild the city and repopulate it with Turks. (Despite this odious "ethnic cleansing" at the beginning of his reign, Mehmed generally treated his non-Islamic subjects well, granting them permission to practice their religion freely, as well as a great deal of local autonomy.) The Byzantine administration was largely preserved intact and was given the task of running the Ottoman Empire.[PARAGRAPH:2]Upon consolidating his control over Constantinople, Mehmed finished off the last remnants of the Byzantine Empire by conquering some small states in Greece and in 1461 he conquered the tiny Empire of Trebizond on the Black Sea. He then tried to extend his empire into Europe, but in 1462 he was defeated by Prince Vlad III (the real Count Dracula) of Wallachia, and at the Battle of Vaslui in 1475 he suffered a major loss to the Moldavian Prince Stefan. These defeats put an end to that campaign. However, Mehmed still had ambition - and plenty of it.[PARAGRAPH:2]Believing that his conquest of Rome made him the legitimate ruler of the late Roman Empire, at the end of his life Mehmed embarked on an ambitious but foolhardy campaign to reunite his divided empire. The campaign began well; the Ottomans invaded Italy, and in 1840 the city of Otranto was easily captured. However, a rebellion in Albania the same year threatened the Ottoman supply lines, forcing the Ottomans to divide their forces. The following year a large Christian army led by the pope pushed the Ottomans from Italy. Mehmed died in 1481, putting an end forever to his dream of recapturing the ancient glory of Rome.[PARAGRAPH:2]In large, history has judged Mehmed kindly. He is recognized for his military success and his strong rule, and later Ottoman sultans would seek to follow his example. Mehmed's conquest of Constantinople was one of the most important events in Western history, signifying the end of the medieval period. His attack upon Italy may have been foolish, but it ultimately did little to harm the young Ottoman Empire that was his legacy.
TEXT.French: [H1]Mehmet II[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan de l'Empire ottoman[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates:[\BOLD] 1432 - 1481 ap. J.-C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biographie:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Mehmet II, dit el-Fatih ("le Conquérant") est le sultan de l'Empire ottoman entre 1451 et 1481 ap. J.-C. Il est surtout connu pour sa prise de la ville de Constantinople, la transformant en nouvelle capitale de l'Empire ottoman et détruisant parallèlement l'Empire byzantin. Mehmet est né en 1432 à Edirne, qui est alors la capitale de l'Etat ottoman. Dès son plus jeune âge, il est fasciné par les questions militaires et lorsqu'il atteint l'âge adulte et accède à la fonction de sultan, en 1451, Mehmet est prêt à attaquer la ville de Constantinople.[PARAGRAPH:2]Au cours de l'histoire millénaire de l'Empire byzantin, Constantinople a résisté à de nombreux sièges et n'a été prise qu'en 1204, lors de la quatrième croisade. Cependant, au XVe siècle, l'Empire byzantin n'est plus que l'ombre de lui-même : s'il possède encore Constantinople, il ne comporte plus que quelques petits territoires hors des murs de la ville, essentiellement en Grèce.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mehmet assiège Constantinople en construisant deux forteresses sur les deux rives des détroits qui encerclent la ville, pour éviter tout renfort par la mer. Lorsque Mehmet attaque en 1453, les Byzantins sont bien moins nombreux : on compte environ 7000 défenseurs de la ville contre une armée d'environ 100 000 Turcs. L'Occident n'est pas prêt à apporter son aide car il reste hostile aux Byzantins en raison de la division entre les Eglises catholique et orthodoxe.[PARAGRAPH:2]A l'aide d'énormes canons primaires, les Ottomans bombardent les murs de Constantinople pendant des semaines. La fréquence de feu est cependant si lente que les défenseurs peuvent réparer la majorité des dommages subis. Le 29 mai, Mehmet donne finalement l'assaut sur une portion endommagée du mur et l'emporte, les attaquants parvenant à gagner les rues de la ville. Le destin de la ville est scellé. Le dernier empereur, Constantin XI, meurt au combat et l'ancien empire disparaît à jamais.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mehmet concède une journée à ses soldats pour piller la ville, ce qui est une pratique courante à cette époque. Une grande partie de la population est alors massacrée, violée ou réduite à l'esclavage. Une fois leur avidité et leur luxure assouvies, Mehmet s'efforce de rebâtir la ville et de la repeupler de Turcs. Malgré cet odieux "nettoyage ethnique" au début de son règne, Mehmet traite en général correctement ses sujets non-islamiques, les autorisant à pratiquer leur religion librement et leur offrant une grande autonomie locale. L'administration byzantine est en grande partie maintenue et est chargée de gérer l'Empire ottoman.[PARAGRAPH:2]Pour renforcer son contrôle sur Constantinople, Mehmet fait disparaître les derniers vestiges de l'Empire byzantin en conquérant quelques petits Etats en Grèce et, en 1461, il s'empare du petit Empire de Trébizonde sur la mer Noire. Il essaie ensuite d'étendre son empire en Europe mais en 1462, il est vaincu par le prince Vlad III de Valachie, l'authentique comte Dracula et lors de la bataille de Vaslui en 1475, il connaît une sévère défaite contre le prince moldave Stefan le Grand. Ces défaites mettent fin à cette campagne. Cependant, Mehmet reste très ambitieux.[PARAGRAPH:2]Pensant que la conquête de Rome ferait de lui le dirigeant légitime du défunt Empire romain, à la fin de sa vie, Mehmet s'engage dans une campagne ambitieuse et téméraire pour réunir l'empire divisé. La campagne commence bien : les Ottomans envahissent l'Italie et, en 1840, ils s'emparent facilement de la ville d'Otrante. Cependant, la même année, une rébellion en Albanie menace les voies de ravitaillement et oblige les Ottomans à diviser leurs forces. L'année suivante, une importante armée chrétienne menée par le pape expulse les Ottomans d'Italie. Mehmet meurt en 1481, enterrant à jamais son rêve de recréer la gloire antique de Rome.[PARAGRAPH:2]De manière générale, Mehmet a été apprécié. Il est reconnu pour ses succès militaires et sa gestion sévère ; il servira ultérieurement de modèle aux sultans ottomans. La prise de Constantinople par Mehmet constitue l'un des événements les plus importants de l'histoire occidentale, mettant fin à la période médiévale. Ses attaques en Italie peuvent paraître ridicules mais elles n'ont finalement que peu affaibli le jeune Empire ottoman qui constituait son héritage.
TEXT.German: [H1]Mehmet II[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan des Osmanenreiches[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] 1432 - 1481 n. Chr.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Mehmet II., der den Beinamen el-Fatih (der Eroberer) trug, war von 1451 bis 1481 nach Christus Sultan des Osmanenreiches. Berühmt wurde er vor allem durch die Einnahme der Stadt Konstantinopel, die er zur Hauptstadt des Osmanischen Reiches machte, und die anschließende Zerschlagung des Byzantinische Reiches. Mehmet wurde 1432 in Edirne geboren, der damaligen Hauptstadt der Osmanen. Die Kriegskunst hatte ihn schon in jungen Jahren fasziniert und als er als Erwachsener zum Sultan aufstieg (1451), war er bereits gut darauf vorbereitet, den Angriff auf Konstantinopel anzuführen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Im Laufe der tausendjährigen Geschichte des Byzantinischen Reiches hatte Konstantinopel zahlreichen Belagerungsangriffen standgehalten. Nur ein einziges Mal wurde die Stadt tatsächlich eingenommen, und zwar 1204 durch die Kreuzfahrer des Vierten Kreuzzugs. Im 15. Jahrhundert war das Byzantinische Reich jedoch nur noch ein Schatten seiner Selbst: Konstantinopel konnte zwar noch gehalten werden, aber außerhalb der Stadtmauern gab es nur noch wenige kleine Gebiete (hauptsächlich Griechenland), die unter byzantinischer Kontrolle standen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mehmet begann die Belagerung, indem er zwei Festungen auf beiden Seiten der Ebenen um die Stadt errichtete und so verhinderte, dass auf dem Seeweg Verstärkung eintreffen konnte. Als Mehmet im Jahr 1453 angriff, waren die Byzantiner deutlich in der Unterzahl: Lediglich 7.000 Defensiveinheiten standen einer Armee von etwa 100.000 Türken gegenüber. Aus dem Westen war keine Unterstützung zu erwarten, weil die dortigen Länder aufgrund der Teilung der katholischen und orthodoxen Kirchen feindlich blieben.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mithilfe einer gigantischen primitiven Kanone nahmen die Osmanen wochenlang die Stadtmauern von Konstantinopel unter Beschuss (allerdings waren die Abstände zwischen den einzelnen Schüssen so groß, dass die Verteidiger den entstandenen Schaden in der Zwischenzeit bereits repariert hatten). Am 29. Mai befahl Mehmet schließlich einen Sturmangriff auf einen beschädigten Bereich der Mauer. Dieser Angriff verlief erfolgreich und die Belagerer konnten sich tatsächlich Zugang zur Stadt verschaffen. Damit war das Schicksal Konstantinopels besiegelt. Der letzte byzantinische Kaiser, Konstantin XI., starb während der Schlacht und das altehrwürdige Reich war für immer ausgelöscht.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mehmet gab seinen Soldaten einen Tag Zeit, um die Stadt zu plündern (das war zur damaligen Zeit so üblich), währenddessen ein großer Teil der Bevölkerung getötet, vergewaltigt oder versklavt wurde. Nachdem seine Soldaten ihre Habgier und Wollust befriedigt hatten, setzte Mehmet alles daran, die Stadt wieder aufzubauen und mit Türken zu bevölkern. (Trotz der abscheulichen "ethnischen Säuberung", die Mehmet zu Beginn seiner Regentschaft durchführte, behandelte er auch seine nicht islamischen Untertanen relativ gut, indem er ihnen gestattete, ihren Glauben ungehindert zu praktizieren und ihnen auch ein hohes Maß an Autonomie zugestand.) Die byzantinische Verwaltungsstruktur blieb größtenteils intakt und hatte nun die Aufgabe, das Osmanenreich aufrechtzuerhalten.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nachdem er seine Vorherrschaft über Konstantinopel gefestigt hatte, vernichtete Mehmet auch die letzten Überreste des Byzantinischen Reiches, indem er zunächst einige kleinere Gebiete in Griechenland und 1461 das winzige Kaiserreich Trapezunt am Schwarzen Meer eroberte. Danach versuchte er, sein Reich nach Europa auszudehnen, wurde aber 1462 von Prinz Vlad III. (dem echten Graf Dracula) in der Wallachei besiegt und erlitt auch 1475 in der Schlacht von Vaslui im Kampf gegen den moldawischen Prinzen Stefan den Großen erhebliche Verluste. Diese Niederlagen setzten seinem Feldzug in dieser Region zwar ein Ende, dessen ungeachtet verfolgte Mehmet aber weiterhin große Ziele - und nicht wenige davon.[PARAGRAPH:2]Da er der festen Überzeugung war, durch die Eroberung Roms zum rechtmäßigen Herrscher des Römischen Reiches aufsteigen zu können, begann Mehmet kurz vor seinem Tod noch einen weiteren ehrgeizigen, aber auch tollkühnen Feldzug, der sein geteiltes Reich einen sollte. Zunächst begann alles gut: Die Osmanen fielen in Italien ein und eroberten 1480 ohne größere Probleme die Stadt Otranto. Allerdings gefährdete eine Rebellion in Albanien im selben Jahr den Nachschub der Osmanen, so dass diese gezwungen waren, ihre Truppen aufzuteilen. Und im darauf folgenden Jahr wurden die Osmanen von einer großen päpstlichen Armee aus Italien vertrieben. Mit Mehmets Tod im Jahr 1481 endete auch sein Traum von der Wiedergeburt des alten Glanzes des Römischen Reiches.[PARAGRAPH:2]Aufgrund seiner Leistungen hat Mehmet seinen Platz in der Geschichte durchaus verdient: Seine militärischen Erfolge und seine geradlinige Regentschaft dienten als Vorbild für viele spätere osmanische Sultane. Darüber hinaus zählt die Eroberung Konstantinopels durch Mehmet II. zu den wichtigsten Ereignissen der westlichen Geschichtsschreibung und kennzeichnete das Ende des Mittelalters. Sein Angriff auf Italien mag dagegen eher dumm gewesen sein, andererseits fügte er dem jungen Osmanischen Reich, das Mehmets Vermächtnis war, aber auch kaum nennenswerten Schaden zu.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Mehmet II[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultano dell'Impero ottomano[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vissuto nel:[\BOLD] 1432 - 1481 d.C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Storia:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Mehmet II, anche noto come el-Fatih ("il Conquistatore") fu sultano dell'Impero ottomano tra il 1451 e il 1481 d.C. Egli è famoso soprattutto per aver conquistato Costantinopoli, facendola diventare la capitale del suo impero e ponendo fine a quello bizantino. Mehmet nacque a Edirne, l'allora capitale dello stato ottomano, nel 1432. Sin da piccolo era affascinato dalle questioni militari e quando raggiunse l'età adulta e salì al trono di sultano (1451), Mehmet era pronto a sferrare l'attacco nel cuore di Bisanzio.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nel corso della storia millenaria dell'Impero bizantino, Costantinopoli aveva resistito a più di un assedio. Era stata conquistata solo una volta, durante la quarta crociata, nel 1204. Ma nel quindicesimo secolo l'Impero bizantino era solo l'ombra di quel ch'era stato in passato: oltre a Costantinopoli comprendeva pochi altri territori, per lo più in Grecia.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mehmet iniziò l'assedio costruendo due fortezze ai lati delle pianure che circondavano la città, impedendo così l'arrivo di rinforzi dal mare. Quando sferrò l'attacco, nel 1453, i Bizantini erano in terribile inferiorità numerica: soltanto 7.000 difensori contro circa 100.000 Turchi. Né potevano sperare in aiuti da occidente, che era loro rimasto ostile per via dello scisma tra la chiesa cattolica e quella ortodossa.[PARAGRAPH:2]Usando degli enormi cannoni primitivi, gli Ottomani colpirono per settimane le mura di Costantinopoli (anche se la frequenza dei colpi era tanto bassa da permettere la riparazione dei danni tra un colpo e l'altro). Il 29 maggio Mehmet ordinò infine l'assalto contro una sezione danneggiata delle mura. L'assalto andò a buon fine e gli invasori si riversarono per le strade della città. Il destino di Costantinopoli era segnato. L'ultimo imperatore, Costantino XI, morì in battaglia e il suo antico impero venne cancellato per sempre.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mehmet concesse ai suoi soldati un giorno per saccheggiare la città (pratica comune del tempo), nel corso del quale buona parte della popolazione venne massacrata, violentata o resa schiava. Quando l'avidità e la bramosia delle sue truppe si fu sedata, Mehmet compì ogni sforzo per ricostruire la città e ripopolarla di Turchi. Nonostante questo odioso atto di pulizia etnica all'inizio del suo regno, Mehmet trattò poi bene i suoi sudditi non islamici, concedendo libertà di religione e larga autonomia alle comunità locali. L'amministrazione bizantina venne preservata quasi per intero affinché gestisse l'Impero ottomano.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dopo aver consolidato il proprio controllo su Costantinopoli, Mehmet cancellò l'Impero bizantino conquistando alcuni staterelli in Grecia e (1461) il piccolo Impero di Trebisonda sul Mar Nero. Egli cercò poi di espandersi in Europa, ma nel 1462 fu sconfitto dal principe Vlad III (il vero conte Dracula) di Valacchia e nella battaglia di Vaslui del 1475 fu pesantemente sconfitto dal principe moldavo Stefan. Mehmet decise perciò di concludere questa campagna, ma la sua ambizione non era ancora stata placata del tutto.[PARAGRAPH:2]Credendo che la conquista di Roma l'avrebbe reso il legittimo sovrano dell'antico Impero romano, negli ultimi anni della sua vita Mehmet si imbarcò in una ambiziosa quanto temeraria campagna per riunire l'impero diviso. La campagna partì bene; gli Ottomani invasero l'Italia e nel 1480 conquistarono facilmente Otranto. Una ribellione in Albania nello stesso anno minacciò tuttavia le linee di rifornimento all'esercito, costringendo gli Ottomani a dividersi su due fronti. L'anno successivo una grande armata cristiana guidata dal Papa respinse gli Ottomani fuori dall'Italia. Mehmet morì nel 1481, senza aver realizzato il suo sogno di ripristinare l'antica gloria di Roma.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nel complesso, la storia giudica Mehmet favorevolmente. A lui vengono riconosciuti numerosi successi militari e una guida sicura, tanto da essere preso a esempio dai sultani suoi successori. La sua conquista di Costantinopoli fu uno degli eventi più importanti della storia dell'occidente, che tradizionalmente segna la fine del periodo medievale. La sua invasione dell'Italia potrebbe sembrare un atto sciocco, ma non ebbe gravi ripercussioni sull'Impero ottomano che aveva contribuito a forgiare.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Mehmet II[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultán del Imperio Otomano[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió:[\BOLD] 1432 - 1481 d. C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biografía:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Mehmet II, conocido también como el-Fatih ("el Conquistador"), fue sultán del Imperio Otomano entre 1451 y 1481 d. C. Su logro más famoso es haber conquistado la ciudad de Constantinopla y haberla convertido en la nueva capital otomana, además de destruir al Imperio Bizantino en el proceso. Mehmet nació en Edirne, capital por entonces del estado otomano, en 1432. Las cuestiones militares lo fascinaron desde muy temprana edad y así, cuando ascendió al trono de sultán (en 1451), estaba preparado para emprender el ataque contra la ciudad de Constantinopla.[PARAGRAPH:2]A lo largo de sus mil años de historia, Constantinopla había soportado numerosos asedios. Solo había sido capturada en una ocasión, durante la Cuarta Cruzada (1204). Pero, en el siglo XV, el Imperio Bizantino no era más que una sombra de su pasada gloria; aunque aún conservaba Constantinopla, más allá de las murallas solo poseía algunos pequeños territorios.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mehmet inició el asedio construyendo un par de fortalezas a ambos lados de los estrechos que rodean la ciudad, para de este modo impedir que recibiera refuerzos por mar. Cuando inició el ataque, los bizantinos se enfrentaron a una inferioridad numérica espantosa. Solo había siete mil defensores para hacer frente a un ejército de aproximadamente cien mil turcos. Y, además, no cabía esperar ayuda desde el oeste, que seguía siendo hostil a los bizantinos a causa de la separación entre las iglesias católica y ortodoxa.[PARAGRAPH:2]Usando unos enormes cañones primitivos, los otomanos bombardearon durante semanas las murallas de la ciudad (aunque la cadencia de fuego era tan limitada que los defensores pudieron reparar gran parte del daño a medida que se producía). Por fin, el 29 de mayo, Mehmet ordenó un ataque contra una sección dañada de la muralla. El asalto se saldó con éxito y los atacantes lograron llegar a las calles de la ciudad. El destino de Constantinopla estaba sellado. El último emperador, Constantino XI, murió en combate, y su antiquísimo imperio se extinguió con él.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mehmet dio a sus soldados un día para saquear la ciudad (una práctica muy normal en la época), durante el que gran parte de la población fue asesinada, violada o esclavizada. Saciada la codicia y la lujuria de sus soldados, Mehmet hizo todo lo posible por reconstruir la ciudad y repoblarla con turcos. A pesar de esta odiosa "limpieza étnica" con la que inició su reinado, en general Mehmet trató bien a sus súbditos no islámicos y les concedió permiso para practicar su religión libremente, además de concederles gran autonomía. La administración bizantina quedó en gran parte intacta y recibió la misión de gobernar el Imperio Otomano.[PARAGRAPH:2]Tras consolidar su control de Constantinopla, Mehmet acabó con los últimos vestigios del Imperio Bizantino con la conquista de los pequeños estados de Grecia y, en 1461, del imperio de Trebisonda, en el mar Negro. A continuación trató de extender su imperio hacia Europa, pero fue derrotado por el príncipe Vlad III (el conde Drácula histórico) de Valaquia en 1462 y, más tarde, en 1475, sufrió un importante revés frente al príncipe moldavo Stefan. Estas derrotas pusieron punto final a esta campaña. Sin embargo, Mehmet seguía teniendo ambiciones, y muchas.[PARAGRAPH:2]Creyendo que la conquista de Roma lo convertiría en el legítimo señor del Imperio Romano, al final de su vida se embarcó en una ambiciosa pero absurda campaña para reunificar el imperio dividido. La campaña tuvo un buen comienzo: los otomanos invadieron Italia y, en 1480, la ciudad de Otranto fue capturada con facilidad. Sin embargo, una rebelión en Albania sucedida el mismo año amenazó sus líneas de abastecimiento y obligó a los otomanos a dividir sus fuerzas. Al año siguiente, un nutrido ejército dirigido por el Papa los expulsó de Italia. Mehmet murió en 1481 y con él se perdió para siempre el sueño de reconquistar la ancestral gloria de Roma.[PARAGRAPH:2]En conjunto, la historia ha deparado a Mehmet un juicio favorable. Se le reconoce su éxito como militar y su firmeza como gobernante, y los posteriores sultanes otomanos lo tomarían como ejemplo. La conquista de Constantinopla por Mehmet fue uno de los acontecimientos más importantes de la historia del mundo occidental, y representa el final de la era medieval. Puede que su ataque a Italia fuera absurdo, pero al fin y al cabo no hizo apenas daño al joven Imperio Otomano, que sería su legado.

TEXT.English: [H1]Meiji the Great[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Emperor of Japan[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1852 - 1912 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Born just eight months before Commodore Matthew Perry and the United States squadron of "Black Ships" came to demand the opening of Japan to foreign trade, Prince Mutsuhito, the 122nd emperor in the traditional count, marked the beginning of a national revolution known as the Meiji Restoration when he ascended to the throne.[PARAGRAPH:2]Once he had taken on the title of Emperor on 3 February 1867, Mutsuhito took the name Meiji (meaning "enlightened government"), and a group of radical nationalists united under his power to take on the Tokugawa shogunate and bring rise to a new era. Only shortly after his ascent to the throne Meiji married Lady Haruko who then became known as Empress Shoken, she was the first woman from the Imperial consort to be given the title kogo or emperor's wife. Shoken, however, bore him no children. Meiji did have children though, fifteen to be exact and to five different ladies in waiting.[PARAGRAPH:2]Though many think of the Meiji Restoration as "bloodless", there was in fact a great civil war fought within Japan shortly after his ascension to the throne. Imperial forces gathered under Meiji's rule and defeated the Tokugawa in the Boshin War of 1868-1869. It was at this time that Meiji moved the capital from Kyoto to Edo, which was then renamed Tokyo, and the Meiji period began in earnest. Though Meiji remained Emperor, the government had now become an oligarchy composed of the greatest military, political, and economic men of Japan.[PARAGRAPH:2]With the Meiji Restoration in progress, the Japanese had sent delegations and students around the world in order to learn and assimilate western arts and sciences; this was done not only to prevent Japan from falling under foreign domination but to enable Japan to compete equally with the Western powers. Sweeping changes were occuring ... although many powerful men from the Satsuma domain in northern Japan had risen to influential positions in the new Meiji government, there was growing dissatisfaction with the direction the country was taking. The modernization (westernization) of the country meant the abolition of the privileged social status of the samurai class and had undermined their financial position. The very rapid and massive changes to Japanese culture, dress, and society appeared to many samurai to be a betrayal of the joi ("expel the barbarian") portion of the Sonno joi justification used to overthrow the former Tokugawa shogunate in the Boshin War. This led to the Satsuma Rebellion, which was a revolt of samurai against the Meiji government from January 29, 1877 to September 24,1877, eleven years into the Meiji Era. It was the last, and the most serious, of a series of armed uprisings against the new government. In a tough series of battles, the samurai were finally defeated. Financially, crushing the Satsuma Rebellion cost the government greatly, forcing Japan off of the gold standard and causing the government to print paper currency. The rebellion was also effectively the end of the samurai class, as the new Imperial Japanese Army built of conscripts without regard to social class had proven itself in battle. Saigo Takamori was labeled as a tragic hero by the people and on February 22, 1889 Emperor Meiji pardoned Saigo posthumously.[PARAGRAPH:2]After securing internal peace, Japan began to reach outward towards imperial ambitions as a great power equal to western nations. The First Sino-Japanese War (1894-1895) was a war fought between Qing Dynasty China and Meiji Japan over the control of Korea which Japan won. The war demonstrated the superiority of Japanese tactics and training as a result of the adoption of a western style military, though it raised tensions between Japan and Russia, which in turn led to the Russo-Japanese War (1904-1905) and grew out of the rival imperialist ambitions of the Russian Empire and Japanese Empire over Manchuria and Korea. In the end, Japan sunk two of Russia's three fleets and defeated Russia in Manchuria, securing victory for Japan.[PARAGRAPH:2]Meiji himself was mainly a figure of leadership that helped the imperialists defeat the Tokugawa shogunate and restore peace to the people. His rule wasn't long, but he played enough part to help establish the Meiji era. It was the restoration that established Japan as a top power in the Pacific and helped it to maintain an important international presence. Little is known about Meiji himself including whether or not he wanted war or peace, or how much power he actually had during the revolution. It is said that the Emperor was more a symbol of unity to the people while it was his ministers that did the actual ruling. Though he may not of done much physically or verbally, his very presence did a lot. Emperor Meiji died in 1912 and was buried in the Graveyard (Fushimi Momoyama Ryo) in Kyoto. After his death, the end of the Meiji era left the people of Japan nervous and unsure of what the future might bring.[PARAGRAPH:2]Meiji symbolized the unity of the people under one government rising up to strike down the Tokugawa shogunate in order to establish a safer and more peaceful future. During his reign, Japan became an industrial power able to compete with the nations of the West. The Meiji shrine in the center of Tokyo was built in his honor.

[H1]Phra Bat Somdet Phra Poramenthra Maha Mongkut Phra Chom Klao Chao Yu Hua[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of Siam[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1804 - 1868 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Phra Bat Somdet Phra Poramenthramaha Mongkut Phra Chom Klao Chao Yu Hua, or Rama IV, known in foreign countries as King Mongkut (18 October 1804 - 1 October 1868), was the fourth monarch of Siam (Thailand) under the House of Chakri, ruling from 1851-1868. He was one of the most revered monarchs of the country.[PARAGRAPH:2]Outside of Thailand, he is best known as the King in the 1951 play and 1956 film The King and I, based on the 1946 film Anna and the King of Siam - in turn based on the 1944 novel about Anna Leonowens' years at his court, from 1862 to 1867.[PARAGRAPH:2]During his reign, the pressure of Western expansionism was felt for the first time in Siam. Mongkut embraced Western innovations and initiated the modernization of Siam, both in technology and culture-earning him the nickname "The Father of Science and Technology" in Siam.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mongkut was also known for his appointment of his brother, Prince Chutamani, as vice-king. Prince Chutamani was crowned in 1851 as King Pinklao. Mongkut himself assured the country that Pinklao should be respected with equal honor to himself. Mongkut's reign was also the time when the power of the House of Bunnag reached its zenith and became the most powerful noble family of Siam.

[H1]Motecuhzoma II Xocoyotzin[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ruler of the Aztec Triple Alliance[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c.1480 - 1520 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Montezuma was Emperor of the Aztec nation from approximately 1502 until its dissolution in 1520. At the start of his reign he was considered a god and was absolute monarch of the entire known world; at the end of his reign he watched a small group of foreigners destroy his empire with ease.[PARAGRAPH:2]Montezuma ruled the Aztecs at the height of their power. His empire controlled a large portion of what is now modern Mexico. They had conquered virtually all other people around them, except for a few other nations, which they deliberately left free (so that they would have somebody left to make war against and to use as sacrifices).[PARAGRAPH:2]Though extremely rich and powerful, Montezuma's nation shamelessly squandered a great portion of its wealth and might. Much like the Egyptians, the Aztecs built huge monuments to their gods and held ever-increasing numbers of expensive religious festivals in which they slaughtered tens of thousands of prisoners and their own people. Montezuma himself lived in great splendor, his clothing made of silver, gold, and brightly-colored feathers. His court was brilliant, though much riddled with corruption and intrigue.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1519, Hernando Cortes led 600 Spanish adventurers with 20 horses and 10 cannon to the shores of Mexico on a mission of exploration. Hearing of the great wealth of the Aztecs, he took his tiny force west, determined to conquer this massive nation of five million. At the start of the march Cortes burned his ships to ensure that his men would not desert him.[PARAGRAPH:2]The natives that first faced Cortes were primitive and divided. They were terrified of the Spanish "demonic" horses and cannon and broke before their accurate musket-fire. Cleverly exploiting their political divisions, Cortes then enlisted the defeated peoples' aid by promising them revenge against the hated Aztecs.[PARAGRAPH:2]Montezuma watched Cortes' approach with fear and bewilderment. His religion told him that one day the god Quetzalcoatl would return in the guise of a light-skinned bearded man, and when that day occurred, the Aztecs were to welcome him with open arms. Surely Cortes was Quetzalcoatl, else how could he command an army of demons? On the other hand, Cortes was clearly bent on the conquest of the empire - should Montezuma not oppose him? Perhaps the sinful Aztecs needed to be punished![PARAGRAPH:2]Eventually, at the desperate urging of his advisors, Montezuma sent an army into the field against the invaders. But they were unable to offer effective resistance and Cortes' forces quickly overwhelmed them. The invaders then marched into the capital city Tenochtitlan virtually unopposed and took Montezuma prisoner. He was eventually killed during an uprising that pushed the invaders out of the city for more than a year.[PARAGRAPH:2]One has to wonder what would have happened if Montezuma had shown Cortes' courage and resolve and mobilized his people when the invaders first arrived. Could the Spanish have conquered Mexico against determined and organized resistance? Perhaps, but perhaps the natives would have held on long enough to learn to master the horse and gun - or at least their fear of them. If so, they would have become a formidable foe indeed.
TEXT.French: [H1]Moctezuma II[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Empereur aztèque[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates:[\BOLD] vers 1480 - 1520 ap. J.-C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biographie:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Moctezuma II dirige l'empire aztèque à partir de 1502 environ et jusqu'à son effondrement en 1520. Au début de son règne, il est considéré comme un dieu et comme le souverain absolu de l'ensemble du monde qu'il connaît ; à la fin de sa vie, il observe un petit groupe d'étrangers détruire sans difficulté son empire.[PARAGRAPH:2]Moctezuma II dirige les Aztèques lorsque leur empire est à son apogée. Il contrôle une grande partie de ce qui correspond à l'actuel Mexique et a conquis pratiquement tous les autres peuples des alentours, exceptées quelques autres nations dont la liberté est délibérément maintenue pour qu'il reste aux Aztèques des ennemis à combattre et à sacrifier.[PARAGRAPH:2]Malgré la richesse et la puissance extrêmes de la nation de Moctezuma II, celles-ci sont dilapidées sans vergogne. Tout comme les Egyptiens, les Aztèques construisent d'immenses monuments pour leurs dieux et organisent de nombreux festivals religieux très coûteux au cours desquels ils massacrent des dizaines de milliers de prisonniers ainsi que des représentants de leur peuple. Moctezuma II vit dans une splendeur incroyable, ses vêtements sont faits d'argent, d'or et de plumes très colorées. Sa cour est éclatante mais elle est rongée par la corruption et les intrigues.[PARAGRAPH:2]En 1519, Hernán Cortés commande une mission d'exploration composée de 600 aventuriers espagnols, 20 chevaux et 10 canons sur les rivages du Mexique. Ayant appris l'existence de l'immense richesse des Aztèques, il conduit ses troupes peu nombreuses vers l'ouest, déterminé à conquérir cet immense empire de cinq millions d'habitants. Au début de sa marche, Cortés brûle ses navires pour s'assurer que ses hommes ne déserteront pas.[PARAGRAPH:2]Les premiers indigènes que Cortés rencontre sont terrifiés par les chevaux et canons "diaboliques" des Espagnols et se rendent devant la précision de leurs arquebuses. Exploitant intelligemment les divisions politiques de ces populations vaincues par les Aztèques, Cortés s'assure leur soutien en leur promettant une revanche contre leur ennemi juré.[PARAGRAPH:2]Moctezuma II observe l'approche de Cortés avec crainte et stupéfaction. D'après sa religion, un jour, le dieu Quetzalcóatl reviendra sous la forme d'un homme barbu à la peau claire et ce jour là, les Aztèques devront l'accueillir à bras ouverts. Moctezuma II est certain que Cortés est Quetzalcóatl, comment pourrait-il sinon commander une armée de démons ? Pourtant, Il est clair que Cortés a l'intention de conquérir l'empire, Moctezuma II ne doit-il donc pas s'opposer à lui ? L'impiété des Aztèques devait peut-être être sanctionnée ![PARAGRAPH:2]Finalement, devant l'insistance de ses conseillers, Moctezuma II envoie son armée sur le terrain afin de combattre les envahisseurs. Elle se montre cependant incapable de résister et les forces de Cortés les submergent rapidement. Les envahisseurs marchent alors sur la capitale de l'empire, Tenochtitlán, qui ne lui offre presque aucune résistance et emprisonnent Moctezuma II. Il est finalement tué lors d'une insurrection qui chasse les envahisseurs de la ville pendant plus d'un an.[PARAGRAPH:2]On peut se demander ce qui se serait passé si Moctezuma II avait fait preuve de courage et de détermination face à Cortés et s'il avait mobilisé son peuple dès l'arrivée des envahisseurs. L'Espagne aurait-elle réussi à conquérir le Mexique s'il avait offert une résistance organisée et déterminée ? Peut-être, mais les indigènes auraient également pu résister suffisamment longtemps pour apprendre à maîtriser les chevaux et les armes, ou du moins la peur qu'ils leur inspiraient. Dans ce cas, ils seraient certainement devenus de redoutables ennemis.
TEXT.German: [H1]Montezuma[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Herrscher der Azteken[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] Um 1480 - 1520 n. Chr.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Montezuma war ab 1502 bis zu seinem Tod im Jahr 1520 der Herrscher der Azteken. Zu Beginn seiner Herrschaft wurde er als Gott und unangefochtener König verehrt. Später musste er jedoch hilflos mitansehen, wie die europäischen Eroberer sein Reich zerstörten.[PARAGRAPH:2]Unter Montezuma erreichte das Aztekenreich den Höhepunkt seiner Macht. Montezuma kontrollierte weite Teile des heutigen Mexikos und hatte fast alle Nachbarstämme ausgelöscht oder unterworfen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Obwohl (oder gerade weil) Montezumas Volk äußerst reich und mächtig war, ging es allzu sorglos mit seinem Reichtum um. Die Azteken errichteten zu Ehren der Götter gewaltige Monumente und feierten kostspielige religiöse Feste, bei denen zehntausende Gefangene und Azteken geopfert wurden. Montezuma selbst lebte im Überfluss. Er schmückte sich mit Silber, Gold und farbenfrohen Federn. Sein Hofstaat war von Korruption und Intrigen geprägt.[PARAGRAPH:2]1519 führte Hernan Cortez 600 spanische Abenteuerer mit Pferden und 10 Kanonen an die mexikanische Küste, um diese zu erforschen. Als er vom großen Reichtum der Azteken hörte, zog er mit seiner kleinen Streitmacht nach Westen, um das riesige Volk zu unterwerfen. Zunächst verbrannte Cortez dazu seine Schiffe, um Fluchtgedanken seiner Männer im Keim zu ersticken.[PARAGRAPH:2]Die Einheimischen, auf die Cortez zunächst traf, waren primitiv und zerstritten. Sie fürchteten die "dämonischen" Pferde und Kanonen der Spanier und hatten deren Musketen nichts entgegenzusetzen. Cortez nutzte die politischen Differenzen geschickt aus und versicherte sich der Unterstützung der besiegten Stämme.[PARAGRAPH:2]Montezuma ließ Cortez ängstlich und verwirrt näher kommen. Die Götter hatten ihm verkündet, dass der Quetzalcoatl eines Tages in Gestalt eines hellhäutigen, bärtigen Mannes zurückkehren würde, und ihn die Azteken mit offenen Armen empfangen sollten. Montezuma hielt Cortez für Quetzalcoatl, zumal er eine Armee von "Dämonen" befehligte. Andererseits wollte Cortez offensichtlich sein Reich erobern ... sollte sich Montezuma ihm nicht entgegenstellen? Oder sollten die Azteken für ihre Sünden bestraft werden?[PARAGRAPH:2]Schließlich entsandte Montezuma auf Anraten seiner Berater eine Armee. Diese wurde von den Spaniern allerdings rasch überrannt. Anschließend marschierten die Invasoren in die Hauptstadt Tenochtitlan ein und nahmen Montezuma gefangen. Wenig später wurde Montezuma während eines Aufstands getötet.[PARAGRAPH:2]Die Frage, was geschehen wäre, wenn sich Montezuma Cortez sofort mutig und entschlossen in den Weg gestellt hätte, muss unbeantwortet bleiben. Hätten die Spanier Mexiko auch dann erobern können? Vielleicht ... vielleicht aber auch nicht ...
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Montezuma[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Imperatore Azteco[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vissuto nel:[\BOLD] ca. 1480 - 1520 d.C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Storia:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Montezuma fu l'imperatore della nazione Azteca dal 1502 fino al suo crollo, nel 1520. All'inizio del suo regno veniva considerato una divinità ed era il monarca assoluto di tutto il mondo conosciuto, poi, alla fine del suo regno, un piccolo gruppo di forestieri distrusse con facilità il suo impero.[PARAGRAPH:2]Montezuma governò gli Aztechi con la forza del proprio potere. Il suo impero controllava gran parte del moderno Messico e gli Aztechi avevano conquistato praticamente tutte le popolazioni circostanti, a eccezione di poche nazioni, lasciate deliberatamente libere per aver qualcuno con cui ingaggiare guerra e da utilizzare come sacrifici).[PARAGRAPH:2]Sebbene estremamente ricca e potente, la nazione di Montezuma sperperò gran parte dei propri beni. Similmente agli Egiziani, gli Aztechi costruirono giganteschi monumenti dedicati alle proprie divinità e celebrarono un numero sempre crescente di costose festività religiose, nelle quali venivano sacrificata decine di migliaia di prigionieri e di persone normali. Montezuma stesso viveva nel lusso e i suoi vestiti erano adornati con oro, argento e piume colorate. La sua corte era illustre, sebbene intaccata dalla corruzione e dagli intrighi.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nel 1519, Hernando Cortés condusse missione esplorativa sulla coste del Messico 600 avventurieri Spagnoli, equipaggiati con 20 cavalli e 10 cannoni. Avendo sentito parlare delle grandi ricchezze degli Aztechi, guidò la sua piccola forza a ovest, determinato a conquistare questa gigantesca nazione di cinque milioni di abitanti. All'inizio della marcia, Cortés bruciò le proprie navi, per assicurarsi che i suoi uomini non disertassero.[PARAGRAPH:2]Gli indigeni che inizialmente affrontarono Cortés erano primitivi e divisi: furono terrorizzati dai cavalli e dai "demoniaci" cannoni e crollarono di fronte al fuoco dei moschetti. Sfruttando astutamente le loro divisioni politiche, Cortés arruolò le popolazioni sconfitte con la promessa di una vendetta contro gli odiati Aztechi.[PARAGRAPH:2]Montezuma assistette all'avanzata di Cortés con timore e perplessità: la sua religione lo aveva avvertito che un giorno il dio Quetzalcoatl sarebbe tornato nella figura di un uomo barbuto dalla pelle chiara e, quando quel giorno sarebbe giunto, gli Aztechi avrebbero dovuto accoglierlo a braccia aperte. Cortés non poteva che essere Quetzalcoatl, chi altri avrebbe potuto comandare un esercito di demoni? D'altra parte, Cortés aveva la chiara intenzione di conquistare il suo impero... non avrebbe forse dovuto opporsi? Forse i peccatori Aztechi dovevano essere puniti![PARAGRAPH:2]Infine, in seguito alle pressioni disperate dei suoi consiglieri, Montezuma inviò un esercito contro gli invasori, ma si rivelò incapace di respingere i nemici e venne rapidamente sopraffatto. Allora gli invasori marciarono sulla capitale, Tenochtitlan, senza incontrare alcuna resistenza e presero Montezuma prigioniero. Infine, Montezuma venne ucciso durante la rivolta che scacciò gli invasori dalla città per oltre un anno.[PARAGRAPH:2]Chissà cosa sarebbe successo se Montezuma avesse dimostrato il coraggio e la determinazione di Cortés e avesse mobilitato il suo popolo subito all'arrivo degli invasori? Sarebbero riusciti allora gli Spagnoli a conquistare il Messico contro una simile resistenza, determinata e organizzata? Forse sì, ma forse gli indigeni avrebbero resistito sufficientemente a lungo da imparare a gestire i cavalli e le armi da fuoco, o almeno a superarne la paura. In questo caso, sarebbero stati degli avversari veramente terribili.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Moctezuma[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Emperador azteca[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió:[\BOLD] c.1480 - 1520 d. C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biografía:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Moctezuma fue emperador de la nación azteca desde 1502 hasta su desaparición, en 1520. Al comienzo de su reinado se le consideraba un dios, y gobernaba como monarca absoluto todo el mundo conocido; al final, presenció la fácil destrucción de su ejército a manos de un pequeño grupo de extranjeros.[PARAGRAPH:2]Moctezuma gobernó a los aztecas en el apogeo de su poder. Su imperio controlaba buena parte del México actual. Sus ejércitos habían conquistado a prácticamente todos los pueblos circundantes, con la excepción de algunas naciones, a las que dejaron deliberadamente en libertad (para tener alguien con quien luchar y de quien extraer víctimas para sus sacrificios).[PARAGRAPH:2]Aunque era extremadamente rica y poderosa, la nación de Moctezuma despilfarró con despreocupación gran parte de su riqueza y poder. Al igual que los antiguos egipcios, los aztecas construyeron enormes monumentos en honor a sus dioses y celebraron un número cada vez mayor de onerosos festivales religiosos, en los que sacrificaban decenas de miles de prisioneros y compatriotas. El propio Moctezuma vivía rodeado de esplendor, y se vestía con un atuendo hecho de plata, oro y plumas de brillantes colores. Tenía una suntuosa corte, aunque aquejada por las lacras de la corrupción y la intriga.[PARAGRAPH:2]En 1519, Hernán Cortés condujo a seiscientos aventureros españoles, veinte caballos y diez cañones a la costa de México en misión de exploración. Al saber de las inmensas riquezas de los aztecas, llevó a su minúsculo ejército al oeste, decidido a conquistar una colosal nación de cinco millones de habitantes. Antes de iniciar la marcha, quemó sus naves para asegurarse de que sus hombres no desertarían.[PARAGRAPH:2]Los primeros nativos con los que se enfrentó eran primitivos y estaban divididos. Los "demoníacos" caballos y cañones de los españoles los aterrorizaron, y se dispersaron bajo el fuego de sus mosquetes. Explotando con astucia sus disensiones internas, Cortés reclutó a los vencidos, prometiéndoles venganza contra los odiados aztecas.[PARAGRAPH:2]Moctezuma recibió la noticia de la llegada de Cortés con temor y perplejidad. Según su religión, el dios Quetzalcoatl regresaría un día con la forma de un hombre barbudo de piel blanca, y el día que eso ocurriera, los aztecas debían darle la bienvenida con los brazos abiertos. Cortés tenía que ser Quetzalcoatl, porque, ¿cómo si no iba a dirigir un ejército de demonios? Por otro lado, era evidente que Cortés estaba decidido a conquistar su imperio. ¿No debía enfrentarse a él? ¡Puede que los pecaminosos aztecas se hubiesen hecho acreedores a un castigo![PARAGRAPH:2]Finalmente, escuchando las desesperadas súplicas de sus consejeros, Moctezuma envió un ejército al encuentro de los invasores. Pero sus hombres no pudieron ofrecer una resistencia eficaz y las fuerzas de Cortés los vencieron con rapidez. Los invasores avanzaron a continuación contra la capital, Tenochtitlán, sin encontrar resistencia, e hicieron prisionero a Moctezuma. El rey encontraría la muerte en el transcurso de un levantamiento que expulsó a los invasores de la ciudad durante más de un año.[PARAGRAPH:2]No queda más remedio que preguntarse qué habría ocurrido si Moctezuma hubiese demostrado el mismo valor y la misma resolución que Cortés y hubiese movilizado a su pueblo la primera vez que aparecieron los invasores. ¿Podrían los españoles haber conquistado México de haberse enfrentado a una resistencia más resuelta y organizada? Puede, pero quizá los nativos hubiesen resistido el tiempo suficiente para aprender a dominar el caballo y el cañón... o al menos el miedo que les inspiraban. De haberlo conseguido, se habrían convertido en unos adversarios formidables.

TEXT.English: [H1]Napoléon Bonaparte[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Emperor of the French, King of Italy[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1769 - 1821 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Napoleon Bonaparte was born in Corsica where he entered military school at ten, displaying a great aptitude for mathematics, history, and geography, as well as total indifference to literature and the humanities. At fourteen he was commissioned as a sub-lieutenant in an artillery regiment. When the French revolution broke out, Napoleon sided with the Revolutionaries and was appointed lieutenant-colonel of artillery, where he quickly made a name for himself as a successful commander. By 1794 he was a brigadier-general, and by 1795 he was appointed command of the French Army of the Interior. He was 25 years of age.[PARAGRAPH:2]Over the next few years Napoleon led French armies, in defense of the new Republic, to major victories over various continental foes, including the extremely powerful Austrians. In 1798 Napoleon sailed against Egypt where he won great land victories; however, the British navy destroyed the French fleet in Egypt, crippling his force. In 1800 Napoleon abandoned his weakened army and returned to France.[PARAGRAPH:2]Napoleon found Paris in a state of political turmoil, which he quickly took advantage of by overthrowing the government and making himself First Consul, with dictator-like power over all of France. An exceptional administrator, he rapidly reorganized the government, repealed the more radical and violent laws of the Revolution, and reopened the churches, gaining the love and respect of the French people, exhausted by years of revolution and chaos.[PARAGRAPH:2]However, France was still at war with most of Europe, and Napoleon once again took to the battlefields, where he won stunning victories against Austria, causing that country and England to make peace. In celebration Napoleon quickly declared himself Emperor and consol for Life.[PARAGRAPH:2]England remained nervous of France's imperial intentions, and war resumed in 1803, with England destroying French shipping on the sea and France putting together a great invasion fleet in the unsuccessful hope of occupying the British Isles. Other countries were equally alarmed by France's actions and they joined the English. France soon found itself facing a daunting alliance that included England, Austria, Russia and Sweden. Acting with amazing speed and cunning, Napoleon used his "interior lines" to concentrate his forces against the dispersed enemy. He rapidly marched across Europe, capturing the capital of Austria and then crushing the Russian forces at the battle of Austerlitz. Austria sued for peace once again, this time giving up all territory in Italy and along the Adriatic.[PARAGRAPH:2]For several more years Napoleon would defeat every foe that came against him. He moved his forces with unbelievable alacrity, and he was always able to bring them against the enemy's weakest spot. He crushed the Prussians, the Spanish, and the Austrians yet again. He tried to improve his political position by marrying his various relatives into the great families of Europe, with minor success.[PARAGRAPH:2]Eventually Napoleon decided that he would never be safe in Europe as long as Russia, aided by the perfidious English, was on his flank, so he led half a million men to Moscow. The Russian forces retreated before his advance, taking or burning anything that might be of use to the invaders, while in the rear Cossack raiders destroyed his supply lines. He did reach and capture Moscow, but once again the Russians had removed or burnt anything there that might feed his men. By September he was forced to retreat, his army reduced to 120,000 weary and starving men. By the end of November his forces had been further reduced to 20,000. Napoleon had lost 96%% of his army.[PARAGRAPH:2]Upon returning to Paris, Napoleon immediately recruited another army of 350,000, but his image of invulnerability was gone and all Europe rose against him. Prussia, Russia and Austria allied against him. England threw more troops into contested Spain. Though Napoleon was to again win famous victories, his enemies sensed victory and continued their relentless attacks. Eventually the allies drove their way into Paris, and Napoleon abdicated. For his trouble he was given ruler ship of the island of Elba, along with an income of six million francs, to be paid by France.[PARAGRAPH:2]But this wasn't enough for Napoleon. Ten months later he re-entered France. The populace immediately went over to his side and he quickly regained his power and titles. He raised an army of 125,000 and headed to Belgium, where an English and Prussian force awaited him. At Waterloo, Napoleon was finally and irrevocably defeated by the English/Prussian forces under the leadership of English general Wellington. This time he was confined for life at the island of Sainte-Hélène, a thousand miles from the coast of Africa. He died there in 1821.[PARAGRAPH:2]Napoleon was one of the most brilliant generals of all time. He moved his troops with astounding rapidity, and he always knew exactly where to strike in order to cause the most damage. He turned out to be a decent ruler and France flourished under his control (until his endless wars sapped her strength and will to fight). His only major flaw was his unending drive for conquest and domination, driving other powers to oppose him for their own preservation. In the end, he just couldn't beat everybody.
TEXT.French: [H1]Napoléon[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Empereur des Français[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates:[\BOLD] 1769 - 1821 ap. J.-C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biographie :[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Napoléon Bonaparte naît en Corse, qui fait actuellement partie de la France. A dix ans, il entre dans une école militaire, il se montre doué en mathématiques, en histoire et en géographie mais totalement indifférent à la littérature et aux arts. A quatorze ans, il est nommé sous-commandant dans un régiment d'artillerie. Lorsque la Révolution française éclate, Napoléon se place aux côtés des révolutionnaires et est nommé lieutenant-colonel d'artillerie, où il se fait rapidement un nom du fait de sa qualité de commandement. Général de brigade en 1794, il est nommé commandant en chef de l'armée de l'Intérieur en 1795, à l'âge de 25 ans.[PARAGRAPH:2]Pendant quelques années, Napoléon dirige les armées françaises dans des combats allant de la défense de la toute nouvelle République à de grandes victoires sur divers autres ennemis continentaux, et notamment les très puissants Autrichiens.
