[H1]Conditional Spawns[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Certain civilizations in Dawn of Civilization only spawn when the right conditions are met. These civilizations are Byzantium, Italy, Thailand, Argentina and Brazil. Their requirements are listed below:[NEWLINE][BOLD]Byzantium:[\BOLD][ICON_BULLET]Greece has to be dead[ICON_BULLET]Rome has to be alive[ICON_BULLET]If the human player controls Rome, the Byzantine spawn can be prevented by having a Solid stability[NEWLINE][BOLD]Italy:[\BOLD][ICON_BULLET]Rome has to be dead[ICON_BULLET]There has to be at least one independent city on the Italian peninsula[NEWLINE][BOLD]Thailand:[\BOLD][ICON_BULLET]Always spawns if the Khmer are dead[ICON_BULLET]Also spawns if the Khmer stability is Shaky or lower[ICON_BULLET]If the human player controls the Khmer, Shaky stability is sufficient to prevent the Thai spawn[NEWLINE][BOLD]Argentina:[\BOLD][ICON_BULLET]The civilization controlling the most cities in the Argentine spawn area must not be Solid[NEWLINE][BOLD]Brazil:[\BOLD][ICON_BULLET]The civilization controlling the most cities in the Brazilian spawn area must not be Solid[PARAGRAPH:2]Dawn of Civilization also allows to configure the spawn of the following civilizations: Tamils, Tibet, Moors, Poland and Congo. While their default setting is to appear in every game, this can be modified by editing the GlobalDefinesAlt.xml file in Assets\XML\. A value of 0 means that the civilization will not appear in the game, while a value greater than 1 means that the civilization will only appear in one out of that many games on average. For instance, setting the value for Poland to 3 means that Poland has a 1/3 chance to appear in your game. However, this setting will be ignored if you are playing as a civilization in the vicinity. For example, when playing Russia, Poland will always appear, regardless of its spawn setting.

[H1]Congresses[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Congresses in Rhye's and Fall represent the phenomenon of informal institutionalization of international politics that began during the 19th century. This includes the idea of the balance of power which manifested itself in the Congress of Vienna and the Concert of Europe, but also international conferences on territorial claims such as the Berlin Congress. They also represent other diplomatic exchanges of territory like the Louisiana Purchase.[PARAGRAPH:2]Congresses take place as soon as the first civilization discovers Nationalism and regularly occur every 15 turns. The ten most powerful civilizations of the world will be invited, and each of them can either claim a city or request to found a colony on unsettled territory. If the majority of civilizations agrees, the request is granted and the city will change hands or a settler will be created on the demanded empty spot. While the human player can decide on claims by voting YES, NO or ABSTAIN, the AI will make its own decisions based on a variety of factors. These include the legitimacy of the claim (e.g. if the claimed city is historical for the civilization or if it already has culture there), the relationship to the demanding and controlling civilizations, including their own interest in the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]If a player claim was considered legitimate by an AI, but not granted because of insufficient relations, or if a player city has been granted to another civilization by the AI, the player can choose a number of options to influence the vote of AI civilizations in their favor. This can happen either through bribery (offering gold) or manipulation (expending espionage points). The player can spend varying amounts of both resources depending on how much they consider influencing their votes necessary. Another way to influence the AI is by agreeing to their own claims in the same congress - or at least avoiding to vote against them![PARAGRAPH:2]If all attempts fail and the congress still gives away one of your cities, you still have the opportunity to refuse handing it over. But be careful, this may cause some of the civilizations that agreed to the request to go to war over your contempt for their decision! The more votes were in favor of reassigning the city, the likelier an individual civilization is to go to war.[PARAGRAPH:2]Congresses are disrupted by global wars, under which different rules apply. A global war takes place when at least half the military power of the world is at war with each other. During these times, no congresses occur because the world is settling its differences on the battlefield instead of the negotiation table. However, when such a global war ends (by the main belligerents agreeing to peace), peace is enforced on all belligerents and a new congress is called to restore order after the war. Such a congress differs from normal congresses in that only belligerents are invited, that only civilizations on the winning side are allowed to make demands, and that it is impossible to request colonizing free territory. Civilizations that have lost the war still can vote on all claims, however. Congresses completely come to an end when the United Nations are built because their formalized approach to multilateral diplomacy makes congresses obsolete.[NEWLINE]If you are familiar with Congresses from Rhye's and Fall, you will notice multiple significant changes and improvements over the previous system, some of which have already been mentioned:[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]In addition to periodic congresses, congresses can also occur after global wars[ICON_BULLET]Participants can also request to settle free territory[ICON_BULLET]A streamlined interaction process so that the entire congress can be resolved in one turn[ICON_BULLET]Significant improvements in computation times[ICON_BULLET]When voting on a claim, the camera centers on the plot or city in question[ICON_BULLET]The option to influence a civilization's decision is only offered when there is actually a chance of success[ICON_BULLET]Attempts to influence a decision are now specific to a certain claim and can be used both to achieve agreement to an own claim and disagreement with a claim on your own cities[ICON_BULLET]There is no limit on how many civilizations can be attempted to be influenced during the same Congress[ICON_BULLET]In addition to bribery by offering gold, votes can also be manipulated by expending espionage[ICON_BULLET]More sophisticated AI decisionmaking: it now takes the legitimacy of the claim, its relations to the claimant and owner, and its own interest in the city into account[ICON_BULLET]More global AI decisionmaking: your own voting behavior influences how the AI treats your claims and the claims against you, global opinion influences how likely AIs are to go to war over a refused claim[ICON_BULLET]No more multiple assignments during the same Congress: if more than one civilization have successfully claimed the same city, it goes to the civilization that received the most votes in favor

[H1]Continents, Countries and Unique Historical Victories[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye has split the World Map into separate continents. No longer will a wonder built in China have an effect on a city in South Africa. With this magic, Rhye also further subdivided the world into countries, even assigning historically accurate city names to individual tiles. These names will be your guide for the UHVs. For most of the territory UHVs (Control the Balkans, Control Mesopotamia, etc.) you will be required to control up to 3 cities in the area. Rome is the most stringent, requiring 2 cities in Iberia, 3 cities in Gaul, 1 city in Britain, 2 cities in Africa, 4 cities in Greece and Byzantium and 2 cities in Egypt.[PARAGRAPH:2]In Dawn of Civilization, the regions that pertain to your UHV are shown in the tile tooltip when hovering over the relevant tiles.
TEXT.French: [H1]Continents, pays et victoires historiques uniques[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye a divisé le monde en continents séparés. Une merveille construite en Chine n'aura donc plus aucun effet sur une ville en Afrique du Sud. Avec sa magie, Rhye a continué de diviser le monde pour créer des pays et a même attribué à des cases des noms de villes historiquement exacts. Ces noms vous serviront de repère pour remporter les victoires historiques uniques (VHU). Pour la plupart des VHU de territoire (Contrôler les Balkans, Contrôler la Mésopotamie, etc.), vous devrez contrôler jusqu'à trois villes dans la zone. C'est avec Rome qu'il sera le plus difficile d'y parvenir, car vous devrez contrôler trois villes en Ibérie, trois en France, trois en Afrique du Nord, deux en Allemagne, une en Angleterre et trois en Italie.
TEXT.German: [H1]Kontinente, Länder und Einzigartige Historische Siege[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye hat die Weltkarte in separate Kontinente aufgeteilt, somit hat ein in China errichtetes Wunder nun keine Auswirkungen mehr auf eine Stadt in Südafrika. Darüber hinaus weist die Karte natürlich auch Länder aus und den einzelnen Geländefeldern innerhalb dieser Länder sind die historisch korrekten Städtenamen zugewiesen, welche Sie wiederum zu Ihren Einzigartigen Historischen Siegen (EHS) führen. Bei den meisten territorialen EHS ("Bringen Sie den Balkan unter Ihre Kontrolle", "Bringen Sie Mesopotamien unter Ihre Kontrolle" etc.) müssen Sie bis zu 3 Städte in der betreffenden Region in Ihren Besitz bringen. Besonders hohe Anforderungen stellt dagegen Rom, denn hier müssen Sie gleich 3 Städte in Iberien, 3 in Frankreich, 3 in Nordafrika, 2 in Deutschland, 1 in England und 3 in Italien einnehmen.[PARAGRAPH:2]In Dawn of Civilization, the Regionen, die für Ihren EHS relevant sind, werden im Tooltip angezeigt, wenn Sie mit dem Cursor auf das entsprechende Feld zeigen.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Continenti, paesi e Vittorie Storiche uniche[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye ha diviso la mappa mondiale in continenti separati. Una meraviglia costruita in Cina non avrà più effetto su una città in Sud Africa. In questo modo Rhye ha anche ulteriormente suddiviso il mondo in Paesi, assegnando addirittura nomi precisi di città alle singole caselle. Questi nomi saranno la tua guida per le vittorie storiche. Per la maggior parte delle vittorie storiche legate ai territori (controlla i Balcani, controlla la Mesopotamia, ecc.) ti verrà chiesto di controllare 3 città nella zona. Roma è la più difficile, visto che servono 3 città in Spagna, 3 in Francia, 3 nell'Africa settentrionale, 2 in Germania, 1 in Inghilterra e 3 in Italia.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Continentes, países y victorias históricas únicas[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye ha dividido el mapamundi en continentes separados. Una maravilla construida en China ya no producirá efectos en Sudáfrica. De la misma manera, Rhye también ha dividido el mundo en países, y ha asignado nombres de ciudades históricas con precisión a las casillas individuales. Esos nombres te servirán de guía para las victorias históricas. En la mayoría de las victorias históricas territoriales (controlar los Balcanes, controlar Mesopotamia, etc.) tendrás que controlar hasta 4 ciudades de la zona. Roma es la más estricta, pues exige 3 ciudades en la península Ibérica, 3 en Francia, 3 en el norte de África, 2 en Alemania, 1 en Inglaterra y 3 en Italia.

TEXT.English: [H1]Diplomatic Institutions[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The [BOLD]Apostolic Palace[\BOLD] and [BOLD]United Nations[\BOLD] have seen some changes in Dawn of Civilizations. Several rules have been modified and certain resolutions were to increase their impact and make them more interesting to interact with. General changes:[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Instead of being directly proportional to population, the number of votes of a civilization are now proportional to the square root of its population. This reduces the influence of large civilizations and makes cooperation with smaller civilizations more important.[ICON_BULLET]Defying resolutions now follows different rules for the two institutions.[ICON_BULLET]When a civilization attempts to win a diplomatic victory, its own votes and the votes of its vassals are disregarded. Instead it needs to win a majority among the remaining votes. This way, the diplomatic victory truly requires diplomacy, and cannot be achieved by military subjugation.[H2]Apostolic Palace[\H2][ICON_BULLET]Only civilizations with Catholic state religions are members of the Apostolic Palace and allowed to vote.[ICON_BULLET]Resolutions that affect all members don't fail only because a member defies it.[ICON_BULLET]Instead, civilizations defying resolutions are not affected by them. The usual penalties (loss of membership, unhappiness, diplomatic penalties) still apply.[ICON_BULLET]Renamed the "Declare War" resolutions to "Crusade". Valid targets are non-members who are at war with a member (defensive crusade) and non-members who control the Catholic holy city or shrine (offensive crusade).[ICON_BULLET]New "Collect Tithe" resolution: all members pay 10% of their treasury of which the Pope receives half.[ICON_BULLET]New "Send Inquisition" resolution: the Pope receives additional espionage against the target civilization.[ICON_BULLET]New "Excommunication" resolution: the target loses membership and receives unhappiness as if they had defied a resolution.[H2]United Nations[\H2][ICON_BULLET]Security Council: only the four civilizations with the highest military power are allowed to defy resolutions.[ICON_BULLET]New "Decolonize City" resolution: Cities on other continents can be forced to be liberated to independents.[ICON_BULLET]New "Release Civilization" resolution: If a civilization can respawn, another civilization controlling their territory can be forced to release it.

[H1]Odds and Ends: Dawn of Civilization[\H1]- The plague can't kill units anymore- Cities of a vassalized civilization can keep control of the first ring around its cities, unless it's also the first ring of a master's city- AI civilizations become more unstable if they survive ahistorically long- The American conqueror event automatically leads to war- It's impossible to vassalize far away civilizations until the discovery of Astronomy- It's impossible to train settlers on other continents than your capital's until the discovery of Astronomy- AI Mongols get additional armies to attack Russia and the Middle East- Pagan Temples can only be built in cities without religions (this does not apply to unique buildings that replace Pagan Temples)- Religion spread to a city turns Pagan Temples into temples of the new religion- Free tech events like Liberalism or Oracle only allow to choose techs from your current or earlier eras- The Seljuks attack the Middle East in the 11th century- Buddhism is founded by building a Hindu Temple- Palace costs scale with the current game era- City tiles with resources give the best production and commerce yield that would be available by building an improvement on them- Missionary success chances depend on the civilization they attempt to proselytize, similar to the natural spread of religions- Independent civilizations can't circumnavigate or get conquerors- The spawn of the Tamil, Tibetan, Moorish, Polish and Congolese civilizations can be disabled or randomized by editing the GlobalDefinesAlt.xml file- Great artist specialists give +1 [ICON_HAPPY]- The human player isn't at war with any civilization on spawn anymore- The location of goody huts on the map is randomly determined at the beginning of the game- Revolutions still cause anarchy during Golden Ages, but the Golden Age counter will not decrease during anarchy- The range of the Blockade mission has been reduced to 2- New set of difficulty levels: Heir, Regent, Monarch, Emperor and Paragon. Regent is the standard difficulty. Monarch and Paragon feature stronger AI opponents than their preceding levels.- You can release a civilization whose territory you control through the Domestic Advisor screen- The BUG mod has been added to the game, providing a wide array of interface improvements- The core area of certain civilizations can expand on specific conditions, such as entering a new era- Civilizations spread some of their culture on city conquest, allowing easier control of the surrounding tiles- Hurry unhappiness now scales with the amount of sacrificed population

[H1]Embassies[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]In order to cut down on communication spam, contact with civs will periodically reset. You will now only keep in contact with civs that are within the Line of Sight of your cities or if any of your units are within the LoS of a foreign city. You may establish permanent contact with a civ by constructing their embassy. Embassies will be destroyed if you are ever at war with a civ.
TEXT.French: [H1]Ambassades[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Afin de limiter les messages inutiles, les contacts avec les civilisations seront réinitialisés périodiquement. Pour rester en contact avec une civilisation, il faudra désormais qu'elle se trouve dans le champ de vision de l'une de vos villes ou que l'une de vos unités soit dans le champ de vision de l'une des siennes. Vous pouvez établir des relations permanentes avec une civilisation en construisant son ambassade. Les ambassades sont détruites si vous entrez en guerre contre leur civilisation.
TEXT.German: [H1]Botschaften[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Um eine "Kommunikationsschwemme" zu vermeiden, wird der Kontakt mit anderen Zivilisationen in regelmäßigen Abständen zurückgesetzt. Dadurch können Sie nur mit den Zivilisationen in Kontakt treten, deren Einheiten oder Städte sich innerhalb der Sichtweite Ihrer Städte befinden bzw., im umgekehrten Fall, wenn sich eine Ihrer Einheiten in Sichtweite einer ihrer Städte befindet. Um einen ständigen Kontakt sicherzustellen, müssen Sie eine Botschaft der jeweiligen Nation errichten - sollten Sie allerdings jemals Krieg gegen eine solche Zivilisation führen, wird deren Botschaft automatisch zerstört.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Ambasciate[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Per ridurre l'eccesso di comunicazioni, periodicamente viene azzerato il contatto con le civiltà. Rimarrai in contatto solo con le civiltà che sono in vista delle tue città o le cui città sono nella visuale di una delle tue unità. Puoi stabilire un contatto permanente con una civiltà costruendo la loro ambasciata. Le ambasciate vengono distrutte, se entri in guerra con la relativa civiltà.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Embajadas[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]El contacto con otras civilizaciones se reiniciará periódicamente para limitar las comunicaciones no deseadas. Solo podrás mantener contacto con las civilizaciones cuando éstas se encuentren dentro de la visual de tus ciudades o cuando una de tus unidades se encuentre en la visual de una ciudad extranjera. Puedes establecer un contacto permanente con una civilización si construyes su embajada. Las embajadas se destruyen si entras en guerra con una civilización.

TEXT.English: [H1]Golden Ages[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]During certain periods of time, some civilizations seem to burst with energy and creativity. The civilization's people become increasingly productive; technological advances come easy to the civilization; and its culture is the envy of the world. Italy during the Renaissance is one such example, and Great Britain in the 19th century another. In Civilization IV, such periods are called "golden ages."[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Entering a Golden Age[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Wonders:[\BOLD] A civilization can enter a golden age by constructing the [LINK=BUILDING_TAJ_MAHAL]Taj Mahal[\LINK] wonder.[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Great People:[\BOLD] A civilization can combine one or more [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Great People[\LINK] of different types to start a golden age. The cost of this method escalates: the first golden age costs one great person, the second costs two, the third one cost three, and so on.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effects of Golden Ages[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]During a golden age, your civilization greatly increases its output of production and commerce, meaning faster build times and research rates. (In game terms, every space within your city's radii that provides commerce produces an extra commerce, and every space that provides production now produces an additional one.) [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Duration of Golden Ages[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Golden ages last eight turns on Normal Speed. If you achieve another golden age while in the midst of one already, the eight additional turns are tacked onto the end of the present golden age. You may increase the length of your Golden Ages by controlling the [LINK=BUILDING_MAUSOLEUM_OF_MAUSSOLLOS]Mausoleum of Maussollos[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]The End of the Age[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Once the golden age ends, your civilization's commerce and production return to normal levels.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.French: [H1]Age d'or[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Il arrive que les civilisations connaissent des périodes durant lesquelles leur énergie et leur créativité atteignent des sommets. La population devient particulièrement productive, le progrès technologique s'accélère et la culture rayonne sur les autres civilisations. L'Italie a connu une telle période au cours de sa Renaissance, ou encore la Grande-Bretagne au XIXe siècle. Ces périodes sont baptisées dans Civilization IV les "Ages d'or".[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Entrer dans un Age d'Or[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Merveilles :[\BOLD] une civilisation peut connaître un Age d'or en construisant la merveille [LINK=TAJ_MAHAL]Taj Mahal[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Personnages illustres : [\BOLD]une civilisation peut sacrifier un [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]personnage illustre[\LINK], ou davantage, pour entrer dans un Age d'or. Le coût de cette méthode tend à augmenter : le premier âge d'or coûte un personnage illustre, le deuxième en coûte deux, le troisième en coûte trois, etc. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effets de l'Age d'or[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]L'Age d'or améliore considérablement la production et le commerce de la civilisation, ce qui signifie qu'elle construit plus vite et que sa recherche est accélérée (cela se traduit dans le jeu par une unité supplémentaire de commerce par case de terrain exploitée produisant déjà du commerce. Il en est de même pour la production). [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Durée de l'Age d'or[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Un Age d'or dure huit tours à vitesse normale. Si vous atteignez un nouvel Age d'or avant la fin du précédent, les huit tours s'additionnent à ceux du précédent. Vous pouvez contrôler la durée de vos Ages d'or grâce au [LINK=BUILDING_MAUSOLEUM_OF_MAUSSOLLOS]Mausolée d'Halicarnasse[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]La fin d'un Age d'or[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Une fois l'Age d'or terminé, le commerce et la production de votre civilisation reviennent à leur (pathétique) niveau normal.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.German: [H1]Goldene Zeitalter[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]In bestimmten Zeitabschnitten ist die Energie und Kreativität einiger Zivilisationen besonders groß. Ist dies der Fall, entwickelt die Bevölkerung der entsprechenden Zivilisationen eine außergewöhnliche Produktivität. Technische Fortschritte werden dadurch mühelos realisiert und alle Welt staunt über die Kultur der Zivilisation. Typische Beispiele für dieses Phänomen sind Italien (während der Renaissance) und Großbritannien (im 19. Jahrhundert). In Civilization IV bezeichen wir derartige Epochen als "Goldene Zeitalter".[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Beginn eines Goldenen Zeitalters[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Wunder:[\BOLD] Eine Zivilisation kann ein Goldenes Zeitalter durch den Bau des [LINK=BUILDING_TAJ_MAHAL]Taj Mahal[\LINK] einleiten.[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Große Persönlichkeiten:[\BOLD] Eine Zivilisation kann verschiedene Typen [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Großer Persönlichkeiten[\LINK] kombinieren, um ein Goldenes Zeitalter einzuleiten. Die Kosten sind dabei kumulativ: Das erste Goldene Zeitalter kostet eine Große Persönlichkeit, das zweite kostet zwei, das dritte kostet drei und so fort.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Auswirkungen eines Goldenen Zeitalters[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Während eines Goldenen Zeitalters erleben die Produktion und die Wirtschaft Ihrer Zivilisation einen bemerkenswerten Aufschwung. Dadurch können Sie deutlich schneller bauen und forschen. (Geländefelder innerhalb des Stadtgebiets, die zum Wirtschaftsertrag beitragen, sind noch produktiver. Geländefelder mit aktiver Produktion produzieren eine zusätzliche Einheit.) [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Dauer des Goldenen Zeitalters[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Ein Goldenes Zeitalter dauert acht Runden bei normaler Spielgeschwindigkeit. Leiten Sie in dieser Zeit ein weiteres Goldenes Zeitalter ein, werden die acht Runden an das Ende des laufenden Zeitalters gehängt. Wenn Sie über das [LINK=BUILDING_MAUSOLEUM_OF_MAUSSOLLOS]Mausoleum von Halikarnassos[\LINK] verfügen, können Sie die Dauer Ihrer Goldenen Zeitalter beeinflussen.[H2]Ende des Zeitalters[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Endet ein Goldenes Zeitalter, fallen Wirtschaft und Produktion der Zivilisation auf ihre normalen Werte zurück.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Ere dell'oro[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Nel corso di alcune epoche storiche, sembra che alcune civiltà abbiano avuto un'impennata di energia e creatività. La popolazione è diventata via via più produttiva, i progressi tecnologici si sono susseguiti a ritmo serrato, e la loro cultura è stata invidiata da tutto il mondo. Un esempio è l'Italia del Rinascimento, o la Gran Bretagna nel XIX secolo. In Civilization IV, questi periodi sono chiamati "età dell'oro".[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Entrare nell'Età dell'Oro[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Meraviglie:[\BOLD] una civiltà può entrare nell'Età dell'oro costruendo il [LINK=BUILDING_TAJ_MAHAL]Taj Mahal[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Grande Personaggio:[\BOLD] Una civiltà può sacrificare uno o più [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]Grandi Personaggi[\LINK] di differenti tipi per iniziare un'età dell'oro. Il costo di questa scelta si intensifica via via: la prima età dell'oro costa un Grande Personaggio, la seconda due, la terza tre, e così via.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Effetti dell'Età dell'Oro[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Nel corso di una età dell'oro, la tua civiltà aumenta la produzione e il commercio, il che significa tempi di costruzione e di ricerca più rapidi. In termini di gioco, ogni casella all'interno del raggio d'azione della città che genera commercio produce un punto commercio aggiuntivo, e ogni casella che produce genera un punto produzione in più. [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Durata dell'Età dell'Oro[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Le età dell'oro durano otto turni alla velocità normale. Se riesci ad entrare in un'altra età dell'oro mentre una è ancora in svolgimento, vengono aggiunti altri otto turni a quella corrente (il che significa che due età dell'oro durano - combinate - sedici turni). Puoi aumentare la durata delle tue età dell'oro controllando il [LINK=BUILDING_MAUSOLEUM_OF_MAUSSOLLOS]Mausoleo di Mausolo[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Termine dell'Età dell'Oro[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Una volta finita l'età dell'oro, il commercio e la produzione della tua civiltà ritornano ai livelli normali.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Edades de oro[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Durante ciertos periodos, algunas civilizaciones parecen rebosar de energía y creatividad. Ese pueblo se hace cada vez más productivo, los avances tecnológicos son más fáciles para esa civilización y su cultura es la envidia de todo el mundo. Un par de ejemplos serían Italia durante el Renacimiento y Gran Bretaña durante el s. XIX. En Civilization IV, a tales periodos se los denomina "edades de oro".[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Entrar en una edad de oro[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Maravillas:[\BOLD] Una civilización puede entrar en una edad de oro si construye la maravilla del [LINK=BUILDING_TAJ_MAHAL]Taj Mahal[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2] [BOLD]Sacrificar a grandes personajes:[\BOLD] Una civilización puede sacrificar uno o más [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_PEOPLE]grandes personajes[\LINK] de distintos tipos para entrar en una edad de oro. El coste de este método va en aumento: la primera edad de oro cuesta un gran personaje; la segunda, dos; la tercera, tres; y así sucesivamente.[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Efectos de las edades de oro[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Durante una edad de oro, la civilización aumentará intensamente sus regímenes de producción y comercio, lo que supone mayor velocidad en la construcción y la investigación (en términos de juego: cada casilla que esté dentro del radio urbano de tus ciudades y que proporcione comercio dará uno más de comercio y cada casilla que proporcione producción pasará a producir uno más). [PARAGRAPH:2][H2]Duración de las edades de oro[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Las edades de oro duran ocho turnos a velocidad Normal. Si logras otra edad de oro mientras estés en medio de una, los ocho turnos adicionales enlazarán con el final de la edad de oro presente. Puedes aumentar la duración de tus edades de oro si controlas el [LINK=BUILDING_MAUSOLEUM_OF_MAUSSOLLOS]Mausoleo de Mausolo[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][H2]El fin de la edad[\H2][PARAGRAPH:2]Cuando una edad de oro termine, el comercio y la producción de tu civilización volverán a sus niveles normales (y patéticos).[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.English: [H1]Historical Starts[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]This is why your game won't start immediately for most Civs. Rhye's mod, above all else, was designed to mirror history. As such, most civs spawn many years into the game, as late as 1822 for Brazil. If you want to play as a late spawning civ now, load up one of the quick starts. Don't worry about being behind; you will start with many units and techs to place you on an even footing with the AIs.[PARAGRAPH:2]In addition to all those units and techs, you may even have some cities flip for you. Although, be aware when playing imperialistic civilizations such as Persia, Rome and Arabia. New civs will carve their empires out of your land! If you refuse to let go of the cities, units in the area will join the resistance for several turns. If you decide to resist the wave of nationalism, make sure your army is large enough to handle defectors!
TEXT.French: [H1]Débuts historiques[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]L'absence de la plupart des civilisations au début du jeu a une explication. Le mod de Rhye a été conçu avant tout pour refléter l'histoire. Par conséquent, beaucoup de civilisations apparaissent assez tardivement dans le jeu, la dernière étant l'Amérique en 1733. Si vous voulez jouer tout de suite avec une des civilisations tardives, chargez une des sauvegardes rapides. Pour que vous ne soyez pas défavorisé par rapport à l'IA, vous commencerez avec un grand nombre de technologies et d'unités.[PARAGRAPH:2]En plus de disposer de nombreuses unités et technologies, vous pourrez même prendre le contrôle de certaines villes. Cependant, prenez garde si vous jouez avec des civilisations impérialistes comme la Perse, l'Arabie ou Rome. De nouvelles civilisations se tailleront un empire dans votre territoire ! Si vous refusez de leur céder vos villes, des unités de la zone rejoindront la résistance pendant plusieurs tours. Si vous décidez de résister à la vague de nationalisme, assurez-vous que votre armée est assez grande pour faire face aux transfuges !
TEXT.German: [H1]Historische Starts[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Diese Einstellung verhindert für die meisten Zivilisationen einen sofortigen Spielstart. Das Rhye's-Mod wurde in erster Linie so entworfen, dass es die Geschichte realistisch widerspiegelt. Dementsprechend stoßen die meisten Zivilisationen - wie geschichtlich belegt - erst nach vielen Jahren zum Spiel hinzu, als letzte Nation Amerika im Jahr 1733. Wenn Sie mit einer dieser erst in späteren Jahren hinzukommenden Nationen spielen wollen, sollten Sie eine der Schnellstartoptionen laden. Und machen Sie sich keine Gedanken darüber, dass Sie in diesem Fall vielleicht zu rückständig starten: Sie werden das Spiel mit zahlreichen Einheiten und Technologien beginnen, damit Sie den KIs ebenbürtig sind.[PARAGRAPH:2]Neben diesen Einheiten und Technologien könnten auch gleich zu Beginn einige Städte ihr Interesse bekunden, sich Ihrer Zivilisation anschließen zu wollen. Hier ist allerdings Vorsicht geboten, wenn Sie das Spiel mit einer imperialistischen Zivilisation wie Persien, Rom oder Arabien bestreiten, denn wiederum später neu entstehende Zivilisationen werden ihre Reiche auf Teilen Ihres bisherigen Territoriums aufbauen! Und sollten Sie sich weigern, Ihre Städte, die sich möglicherweise einer solchen neuen Nation anschließen möchte, ziehen zu lassen, werden sich die umliegenden Einheiten einige Runden lang dem Widerstand anschließen. Für den Fall, dass Sie vorhaben, sich der Welle des Nationalismus zu widersetzen, sollten Sie sicherstellen, dass Ihre Armee groß genug ist, um mit Überläufern fertig zu werden!
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Avvii storici[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Ecco perché la partita non comincerà immediatamente, per la maggior parte delle civiltà. Questo mod, per prima cosa, è stato pensato per riprodurre la storia, per cui molte civiltà nasceranno molti anni dopo l'inizio del gioco, fino al 1733 dell'America. Se vuoi giocare subito una delle civiltà che nascono tardi, carica uno degli avvii rapidi. Non preoccuparti di restare indietro: comincerai con abbastanza unità e tecnologie da metterti alla pari con l'IA.[PARAGRAPH:2]Oltre ad avere tutte le unità e tecnologie, potresti addirittura ottenere che qualche città cambi schieramento. Attento però, che quando giochi con civiltà imperialiste come quella persiana, romana o araba, le nuove civiltà creeranno i propri imperi con le tue terre! Se ti rifiuti di lasciar andare le città, le unità della zona si uniranno per diversi turni alla resistenza. Se decidi di resistere all'ondata di nazionalismo assicurati che il tuo esercito sia abbastanza grande da gestire i disertori!
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Comienzos históricos[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]A continuación se explica por qué la mayoría de las civilizaciones no comenzarán inmediatamente. El mod de Rhye ha sido diseñado para reflejar la historia por encima de todo lo demás. Por ello, la mayoría de las civilizaciones aparecen tarde en la partida, como Estados Unidos, que lo hace en 1733. Si quieres jugar con una de las civilizaciones que aparecen tarde, carga uno de los inicios rápidos. Sin embargo, no te quedarás atrás, pues comenzarás con muchas unidades y tecnologías que equilibrarán tu posición con la de las IA.[PARAGRAPH:2]Además de todas esas unidades y tecnologías, también podrían unírsete algunas ciudades. Ten cuidado al jugar con algunas civilizaciones imperialistas, como Persia, Roma y Arabia, ¡pues surgirán nuevas civilizaciones que querrán labrar su imperio con tus territorios! Si te niegas a hacer concesiones a las ciudades, las unidades de la zona se unirán a la resistencia durante varios turnos. Si decides resistirte al empuje del nacionalismo, ¡no olvides mantener un ejército lo bastante grande como para que las deserciones no sean un problema!

TEXT.English: [H1]Mercenaries[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The Mercenary screen can be accessed by clicking the small axe icon in the upper left of the screen. Here you can hire foreign units for your wars. Be warned that it takes several turns for the units to appear in your cities. Also, you can offer your own units for hire by clicking the hand with scroll icon while a unit is in a city. Mercenaries become obsolete after the discovery of Nationalism.
TEXT.French: [H1]Mercenaires[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Pour accéder à l'écran des mercenaires, cliquez sur la petite icône en forme de hache située dans la partie supérieure gauche de l'écran. A partir de cet écran, vous pouvez engager des unités étrangères pour guerroyer. Notez qu'il faut plusieurs tours aux unités pour atteindre vos villes. Vous pouvez également louer les services de vos unités. Pour cela, cliquez sur la main tenant un parchemin quand votre unité se trouve dans une ville. Les mercenaires deviennent inutiles après la découverte du nationalisme.
TEXT.German: [H1]Söldner[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Mit einem Klick auf das kleine Axt-Symbol in der linken oberen Ecke des Bildschirms gelangen Sie in den Söldner-Bildschirm. Hier können Sie fremde Einheiten anheuern, die für Sie in den Krieg ziehen. Beachten Sie jedoch, dass es einige Runden dauern wird, bis diese Einheiten in Ihren Städten zur Verfügung stehen. Darüber hinaus können Sie auch Ihre eigenen Einheiten als Söldner feilbieten, indem Sie das Hand-Symbol mit der Schriftrolle anklicken, während sich eine Einheit in einer Stadt befindet. Söldner werden mit der Entdeckung des "Nationalismus" überflüssig.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Mercenari[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Puoi accedere alla schermata dei mercenari cliccando sulla piccola ascia in alto a sinistra sullo schermo. Qui puoi assumere unità straniere per le tue guerre. Attenzione che ci voglio molti turni prima che le unità appaiano nelle tue città. Inoltre puoi affittare le tue unità cliccando sull'icona della mano con la pergamena, mentre l'unità è in una città. I mercenari diventano obsoleti dopo la scoperta del nazionalismo.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Mercenarios[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Se puede acceder a la pantalla de mercenarios si se hace clic en el pequeño icono con forma de hacha que hay en la parte superior izquierda de la pantalla. Desde allí podrás contratar unidades extranjeras para que luchen en tu bando. Sin embargo, ten en cuenta que las unidades tardarán varios turnos en aparecer en tus ciudades. Además, también puedes ofrecer tus propias unidades si haces clic en el icono de la mano con el pergamino cuando una unidad se encuentre en una ciudad. Los mercenarios se quedan obsoletos tras el descubrimiento del Nacionalismo.

TEXT.English: [H1]Mercenaries[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Mercenaries are soldiers who fight primarily for private gain, usually with little regard for ideological, national, political, or moral considerations. However, when the term is used to refer to a soldier in a regular national army, it is usually considered an insult.[PARAGRAPH:2][PARAGRAPH:2]Mercenaries have seen regular deployment in battle since the time of Ancient Egypt and Carthage, up through the 16th century, including the famous Swiss Guard and the Landsknechts. In the game, Mercenaries can be hired only until the discovery of Nationalism, which changed the conception of armies and caused a rapid decline in Mercenary usage.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.French: [H1]Mercenaires[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Les mercenaires sont des soldats qui se battent avant tout pour leur profit personnel, et n'ont que peu de considérations idéologiques, territoriales, politiques ou morales. Lorsque ce terme est utilisé pour un soldat d'une armée régulière, c'est en général insultant.[PARAGRAPH:2][PARAGRAPH:2]Les mercenaires ont souvent été employés depuis l'époque de l'Egypte ancienne et de Carthage, jusqu'au 16e siècle, avec les célèbres Gardes Suisses et les Lansquenets. Vous pouvez recruter des mercenaires jusqu'à la découverte du nationalisme, qui modifie la conception des armées et entraîne un rapide déclin de l'utilisation des mercenaires.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.German: [H1]Söldner[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Söldner sind Kämpfer, die meist ohne jede Rücksicht auf ideologische, patriotische, politische oder moralische Überlegungen in erster Linie ihre persönlichen Interessen verfolgen. Manchmal wird der Begriff auch als Bezeichnung für Soldaten verwendet, die in einer regulären nationalen Armee ihren Dienst verrichten, in diesem Fall ist er jedoch in aller Regel als Beleidigung zu verstehen.[PARAGRAPH:2][PARAGRAPH:2]Der Einsatz von Söldnern in der Schlacht war seit der Zeit des antiken Ägyptens und Karthagos bis ins 16. Jahrhundert, beispielsweise mit der Schweizergarde und den Landsknechten, weit verbreitet. Im Spiel können Söldner bis zur Entdeckung des "Nationalismus" angeheuert werden, der das Prinzip des strukturellen Aufbaus einer Armee so stark veränderte, dass er das Ende des Söldnertums einläutete.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Mercenari[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]I mercenari sono soldati che combattono principalmente per un tornaconto privato, di solito senza considerazioni di ordine ideologico, nazionale, politico o morale. Però quando il termine viene utilizzato riferendosi a un soldato di un regolare esercito nazionale, è considerato un insulto.[PARAGRAPH:2][PARAGRAPH:2]I mercenari sono stati impiegati in battaglia fin dai tempi dell'antico Egitto e di Cartagine fino al sedicesimo secolo, e tra l'altro includono i famosi Lanzichenecchi e la Guardia Svizzera. Nel gioco i mercenari possono essere assoldati solo fino alla scoperta del nazionalismo, che ha rivoluzionato la concezione degli eserciti e ha causato un rapido declino nell'utilizzo di truppe a pagamento.[PARAGRAPH:2]
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Mercenarios[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Los mercenarios son soldados a los que no les interesan las consideraciones ideológicas, nacionales, políticas ni morales y que combaten fundamentalmente en busca de un beneficio propio. Sin embargo, cuando se utiliza este término para referirse a un soldado de un ejército permanente, suele considerarse un insulto.[PARAGRAPH:2][PARAGRAPH:2]Los mercenarios han participado en guerras con regularidad desde la época del antiguo Egipto y Cartago hasta el siglo XVI, como la famosa Guardia Suiza y los Lansquenetes. En el juego, solo se pueden contratar mercenarios hasta el descubrimiento del nacionalismo, que cambió la concepción de los ejércitos y provocó un rápido declive del empleo de mercenarios.[PARAGRAPH:2]

TEXT.English: [H1]Corporations in Dawn of Civilization[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Corporation headquarters and executives have been removed in Dawn of Civilization. Instead, corporations spread on their own to cities that can attract them. To be able to attract a corporation, you need to have the associated technology and control at least one of the consumed resources. The chance increases by acquiring more resources, constructing appropriate buildings or adopting the Free Market civic. The number of cities per corporation is limited, so corporations can also leave one city and move to another that fulfills its requirements better. Certain corporations also compete with each other, reducing the chance of being present in the same city.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Silk Route and Trading Company corporations behave differently from the others. They don't require the Corporation technology to spread to your cities, but are limited to certain historical regions of the map. Also, they expire after a certain date and start to leave your cities.

[H1]Odds and Ends[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]- Jungles are impassable by most units and cannot be chopped until Biology.- Swamp is a new tile, and it may never be cleared.- A new luxury resource, Cotton, has been added.- Shrines are capped at +20- Corporations will consume a maximum of 12 resources.- Tech costs increase as you grow- Nukes do much more damage and are now a deadly weapon.- Your first few Barbarian battles are guaranteed wins. Don't waste them on Animals!
TEXT.French: [H1]Précisions[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]- La plupart des unités ne peuvent ni traverser les jungles ni les défricher avant la découverte de la biologie.- Le marais est une nouvelle case impossible à aménager.- Une nouvelle ressource de luxe, le coton, a été ajoutée.- Le revenu des sanctuaires est limité à 20 pièces d'or par tour.- Les sociétés commerciales consomment 12 ressources au maximum.- Le coût des technologies augmente à mesure que vous vous développez.- Les bombes atomiques font bien plus de dégâts. Ce sont maintenant des armes mortelles.- Il n'y a qu'une seule vitesse de jeu en raison des événements scriptés.- Vous êtes assuré de gagner vos premières batailles contre des barbares. Ne les gaspillez pas contre des animaux !
TEXT.German: [H1]Sonstiges[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]- Dschungel-Geländefelder sind für die meisten Einheiten unpassierbar und können bis zur Entdeckung der "Biologie" nicht gerodet werden.- Das Moor ist eine neue Geländeart, die nicht entfernt werden kann.- Mit der Baumwolle wurde ein neues Luxusgut ergänzt.- Schreine sind auf +20 GPR begrenzt.- Kapitalgesellschaften verwerten maximal 12 Ressourcen.- Technologiekosten steigen mit dem Zivilisationswachstum an.- Atomraketen verursachen mehr Schaden und stellen jetzt tödliche Waffen dar.- Bei Ihren ersten Barbarenkämpfen ist Ihnen der Sieg sicher. Verschwenden Sie diesen Vorteil nicht auf Kämpfchen gegen Tiere!
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Varie ed eventuali[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]- Le giungle sono insuperabili dalla maggior parte delle unità e non possono essere abbattute fino alla scoperta della biologia.- La palude è una nuova casella e non può essere bonificata.- È stata aggiunta una nuova materia di lusso, il cotone.- I santuari sono limitati a un massimo di +20 OPT.- Le corporazioni consumeranno un massimo di 12 risorse.- A mano a mano che cresci le tecnologie costano di più.- Le bombe nucleari fanno molti più danni e sono un'arma mortale.- C'è una sola velocità, per via degli eventi programmati.- Le tue prime battaglie coi barbari saranno sicuramente delle vittorie. Non sprecarle con gli animali!
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Demás aspectos[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]- La mayoría de las unidades no pueden atravesar junglas, y estas últimas solo se pueden talar con Biología.- Nuevas casillas de ciénaga y pantano, que no se puede despejar nunca.- Se ha añadido un nuevo recurso de lujo: el algodón.- Los santuarios no producen más de 20 monedas por turno.- Las corporaciones consumirán un máximo de 12 recursos.- Los costes de tecnología aumentan con el crecimiento.- Las armas nucleares hacen mucho más daño y son verdaderamente mortales.- Como consecuencia de los sucesos programados, solo existe una velocidad.- Tus primeros combates contra bárbaros serán victorias seguras. ¡No los desperdicies con animales!

TEXT.English: [H1]Plague[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The most controversial and bemoaned addition to this mod, Plague has made RFC more dynamic than even Stability. There are 5 pre-determined Plague spawns. They occur roughly at 400AD, 1300AD, 1650AD and 1850AD. There is a fifth plague that spawns only in Meso-America when Europeans first make contact. This is meant to simulate the spread of Smallpox. But fear not! There are many ways for you to control the spread and duration of the plague.[PARAGRAPH:2]Plague spreads through foreign contact and proximity to infected cities. You can limit this spread by canceling open borders, running Mercantilism and not building Embassies. The major determining factor in catching plague is your health surplus. Having far more health bonuses than unhealthiness will prevent the plague from spreading to your cities. Even if you don't reach the preventative threshold, high health will lessen the duration and severity of the plague. Granaries, Aqueducts, Harbors and Grocers are all vital to any populous empire. Even with these precautions, once a city catches plague, there is little you can do to prevent the spread to neighboring cities. Discovering Medicine will stop the plague from spreading regardless of your healthiness.
TEXT.French: [H1]Peste[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Bien que ce soit l'ajout le plus controversé et le plus contesté de ce mod, la peste donne encore plus de dynamisme à RFC que la stabilité. Il y a cinq épidémies de peste prédéfinies. Elles éclatent approximativement vers 400 apr. J.-C., 1300 apr. J.-C., 1650 apr. J.-C. et 1850 apr. J.-C. La cinquième épidémie de peste éclate seulement en Méso-Amérique, quand les Européens la découvrent pour la première fois. Cette dernière épidémie sert à simuler la propagation de la variole. Mais n'ayez crainte ! Vous pouvez contrôler la propagation et la durée de la peste de nombreuses façons.[PARAGRAPH:2]La propagation de la peste est favorisée par les contacts avec l'étranger et la proximité de villes contaminées. Vous pouvez limiter cette propagation en annulant les accords de libre passage, en instaurant le mercantilisme et en évitant de construire des ambassades. Le facteur déterminant dans l'apparition de la peste est le niveau de santé. Si vous avez bien plus de bonus de santé que de malus, vos villes ne seront pas touchées par la peste. Même si vous n'atteignez pas le seuil d'immunisation, une santé élevée réduira la durée et la gravité de la maladie. Les greniers, les aqueducs, les ports et les épiceries sont essentiels pour tout empire peuplé. Si, malgré vos précautions, la peste apparaissait dans l'une de vos villes, vous ne pourrez pas faire grand-chose pour empêcher l'épidémie de gagner les villes voisines. En découvrant la médecine, vous pouvez enrayer la propagation de la peste, quel que soit votre niveau de santé.
TEXT.German: [H1]Pest[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Die kontroverseste und umstrittenste Neuerung in diesem Mod ist, dass die Pest RFC noch dynamischer gestaltet als die Stabilität. Es gibt 5 vorbestimmte Pestausbrüche, die in etwa um 400 n. Chr., 1300 n. Chr., 1650 n. Chr. und 1850 n. Chr. stattfinden. Die fünfte Pestepidemie bricht nur in Mesoamerika aus, und zwar beim ersten Kontakt mit den Europäern - damit soll die Verbreitung der Pocken simuliert werden. Aber keine Sorge: Sie haben viele Möglichkeiten, die Ausbreitung und Dauer der Pest zu kontrollieren.[PARAGRAPH:2]Die Verbreitung der Pest erfolgt durch den Kontakt mit Fremden und die Nähe zu infizierten Städten. Sie können sie aber eindämmen, indem Sie Offene-Grenzen-Abkommen aufheben, die Staatsform "Merkantilismus" anwenden und keinerlei Botschaftsgebäude errichten. Der entscheidende Faktor bei der Bekämpfung der Pest ist jedoch Ihr "Gesundheitsüberschuss": Wenn Sie deutlich mehr Gesundheitsboni vorweisen können als Krankheitsfaktoren, wird dies die Ausbreitung der Pest in Ihren Städten verhindern. Und auch wenn Sie den präventiven Schwellenwert nicht erreichen, wird ein hoher Gesundheitswert die Dauer und Intensität der Pest mindern. Kornspeicher, Aquädukte, Häfen und Krämer sind für eine bevölkerungsreiche Nation allerdings unerlässlich. Trotz aller Vorsichtsmaßnahmen gibt es, wenn die Pest erst einmal in einer Stadt aufgetreten ist, nur wenig Möglichkeiten, ein Übergreifen auf benachbarte Städte zu unterbinden - lediglich die Entdeckung der "Medizin" kann die Pest unabhängig von dem aktuellen Gesundheitswert stoppen.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Peste[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]La più controversa e criticata aggiunta a questo mod è la peste, che lo ha reso dinamico ancor più della stabilità. La peste si verifica in 5 occasioni predeterminate: circa nel 400 d.C., 1300 d.C:, 1650 d.C: e 1850 d.C. La quinta volta accade solo nel centro America, all'arrivo degli europei; l'intento è simulare lo scoppio dell'epidemia di vaiolo. Ma non temere! Hai molti modi per controllare la diffusione e la durata delle epidemie.[PARAGRAPH:2]La peste si diffonde tramite il contatto con gli stranieri e la vicinanza alle città infette. Puoi limitare questo tipo di diffusione annullando il diritto di passaggio, usando il mercantilismo come forma di governo e non costruendo ambasciate. Il fattore più determinante è comunque il surplus di salute. Se i bonus di salute superano la mancanza di salute impedirai alla peste di diffondersi nelle tue città. Anche se non raggiungi il limite di prevenzione, tanta salute farà in modo che la peste duri meno e sia meno grave. Granai, acquedotti, porti e droghieri sono essenziali per la vita di qualsiasi impero popoloso. Anche con queste precauzioni, una volta che una città ha preso la peste puoi fare ben poco per impedire che si diffonda nelle città vicine. Se scopri la medicina impedirai la diffusione della peste a prescindere dalla salute.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Peste[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]La novedad más polémica de este mod es la relativa a la peste, ya que ha suscitado aún más comentarios de la comunidad que la relativa a la estabilidad. Hay cinco momentos predeterminados en los que surgirá la peste. Ésta se producirá aproximadamente en torno a los años 400, 1300, 1650 y 1850, todos ellos d. C. Y la quinta peste se produce únicamente en Centroamérica, cuando se traban los primeros contactos con los europeos (esta última simulará la propagación de la viruela). ¡Pero no temas! Existen muchas formas de controlar la propagación y la duración de la peste.[PARAGRAPH:2]La peste se propaga gracias al contacto con extranjeros y a la proximidad con ciudades infectadas. Puedes limitar su propagación si cierras las fronteras, empleas el Mercantilismo y evitas abrir embajadas. El factor más determinante a la hora de controlar la peste es tu excedente de salud. Disponer de más bonificaciones de salud que de insalubridad evitará que la peste se extienda por tus ciudades. Incluso si no alcanzas el umbral preventivo, una salud elevada reducirá la duración y la gravedad de la peste. Los graneros, los acueductos, los puertos y los colmados son vitales para conseguir un imperio bien poblado. Si la peste entra en una ciudad a pesar de todas esas precauciones, poco puede hacerse para evitar que se extienda a las ciudades vecinas. El descubrimiento de la medicina evitará que la peste se extienda, independientemente de tu nivel de salud.

TEXT.English: [H1]Reformation[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The Protestant religion is not founded like the other religions. Instead, the discovery of Printing Press by a civilization with Catholic state religion triggers the Reformation. All Catholic civilizations then have to decide if they want to convert to Protestantism and gain additional gold from the dissolution of monasteries, foregoing the benefits of the Apostolic Palace. When a civilization decides to convert, all of its cities immediately change their religion to Protestantism. Large cities also have a chance of keeping Catholicism or gaining Protestantism regardless of your decision.

[H1]Rebirths and Resurrections in Dawn of Civilization[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]There are different mechanics for collapsed civilizations to return into the game. Resurrection refers to the rules already present in vanilla RFC that allow a civilization to return if its core is controlled by independents or an unstable civilization. This effect is limited to certain periods in Dawn of Civilization, to prevent ahistorical respawns of ancient and classical civs. Also, it's not necessary to discover Nationalism to enable this mechanism, although it increases the probability of resurrections. This means that you will see resurrections occur earlier in the game. Outside of periodic checks, these resurrections can also occur when an unstable civilization collapses - if their territory includes the core of a civilization that can return, these cities will become part of this civilization instead of being independent.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dawn of Civilization also adds another mechanic that is referred to as rebirths. These are scripted and return a specific dead civ at specific dates, if certain conditions are met. Also, the faction now represents a completely new civilization with UU, UB, UP and UHV. Players can take control of these civilizations and complete their victory goals by switching to them, even if they have switched once already. Currently, this mechanic covers the rebirths of Persia as Iran, Maya as Colombia and Aztecs as Mexico.

[H1]Welcome to Rhye's and Fall of Civilization[\H1][PARAGRAPH:0]v1.187[PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye's and Fall of Civilization is a mod based on a map of the world, that attempts to make your single-player game a realistic simulator of history on Earth. It is the sequel to "Rhye's of Civilization", one of the most popular modpacks for Civilization III. [PARAGRAPH:2]The mod revolves around the historic rise and fall of civilizations: they won't start all at the same time, but at appropriate dates. The human player can choose a late start (waiting for the game to play by itself) or take the control of one of the early civs and switch to another one later on. Civilizations will fall by many factors, including civil wars caused by inner instability, and scripted barbarian attacks.[PARAGRAPH:2]Each civilization is heavily differentiated from the others, thanks to the UPs (Unique Powers), the UHVs (Unique Historical Victory conditions), and a unique AI that will found cities in their historical place, with their historical name.[PARAGRAPH:2]Other additions include plague outbreaks, embassies, world congresses where cities are traded, dynamic spread of the resources, and new flag and terrain graphics.[PARAGRAPH:2]More detailed info is provided in the readme. For any other question you can visit the official site (http://rhye.civfanatics.net), the development forum (http://forums.civfanatics.com/forumdisplay.php?f=204) or the wiki (http://rhye.civfanatics.net/wiki/), which contains useful strategy guides.
TEXT.French: [H1]Bienvenue à "Rhye's and Fall of Civilization"[\H1][PARAGRAPH:0]v1.187[PARAGRAPH:2]"Rhye's and Fall of Civilization" est un mod basé sur une carte du monde, qui tente de rendre votre partie aussi proche de la réalité historique que possible. Il s'agit de la suite de "Rhye's of Civilization", l'un des mods les plus populaires de Civilization III . [PARAGRAPH:2]Ce mod est basé sur l'essor et la chute des civilisations tels que ces événements se sont réellement déroulés. Toutes ces civilisations ne démarreront pas en même temps, mais aux dates appropriées. Le joueur peut choisir de commencer plus tard (la partie démarre alors sans lui) ou de prendre le contrôle de l'une des premières civilisations pour en changer plus tard. Les civilisations chuteront en raison de nombreux facteurs, dont les guerres civiles causées par l'instabilité du pays et les attaques barbares scénarisées.[PARAGRAPH:2]Chaque civilisation est extrêmement différente des autres, grâce aux PU (Pouvoirs uniques), aux VHU (conditions de Victoires Historiques Uniques), et à une IA unique qui fondera les villes dans leur site historique et leur donnera le nom qu’elles ont réellement porté.[PARAGRAPH:2]Parmi les nouveautés, citons les épidémies de peste, les ambassades, les congrès mondiaux où sont échangées les villes, la propagation dynamique des ressources et de nouveaux graphismes pour les drapeaux et les terrains.[PARAGRAPH:2]Vous trouverez de plus amples informations dans la section Lisez-moi. Vous pouvez également consulter le site officiel (http://rhye.civfanatics.net), le forum de développement (http://forums.civfanatics.com/forumdisplay.php?f=204) ou l'encyclopédie (http://rhye.civfanatics.net/wiki/), laquelle contient de nombreux conseils stratégiques.
TEXT.German: [H1]Willkommen zu Rhye's and Fall of Civilization[\H1][PARAGRAPH:0]v1.187[PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye's and Fall of Civilization ist ein Mod, das auf einer Weltkarte basiert, um das Einzelspielerspiel zu einer realistischen Simulation der Geschichte der Erde zu machen. Es ist die Fortsetzung von "Rhye's of Civilization", eines der bekanntesten Mod-Pakete für Civilization III. [PARAGRAPH:2]Das Mod handelt vom historischen Aufstieg und Fall der Zivilisationen: Sie beginnen nicht alle zur selben Zeit, sondern zum passenden Zeitpunkt. Der Spieler kann einen späten Start wählen (und warten, bis das Spiel so weit vorangeschritten ist) oder die Kontrolle über eine der frühen Zivilisationen übernehmen und später dann zu einer anderen wechseln. Der Fall von Zivilisationen wird von vielen Faktoren beeinflusst, wie etwa Bürgerkriege, die durch innere Instabilität ausgelöst werden, und programmierte Angriffe von Barbaren.[PARAGRAPH:2]Jede Zivilisation unterscheidet sich von den anderen durch die EMs (Einzigartigen Mächte), die EHS (Einzigartigen historischen Siegbedingungen) und eine einzigartige KI, die Städte an historischen Orten und mit ihrem historischen Namen errichten wird.[PARAGRAPH:2]Andere Ergänzungen beinhalten den Ausbruch der Pest, Botschaften, Weltkongresse, bei denen ganze Städte verkauft werden, dynamische Verteilung der Ressourcen und neue Gelände- und Flaggengrafiken.[PARAGRAPH:2]Genauere Informationen finden Sie im ReadMe. Für weitergehende Fragen, sehen Sie bitte auf der offiziellen Website (http://rhye.civfanatics.net), dem Entwicklerforum (http://forums.civfanatics.com/forumdisplay.php?f=204) oder der Wikipedia (http://rhye.civfanatics.net/wiki/) nach. Hier finden Sie hilfreiche Strategietipps.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Benvenuto a Rhye's and Fall[\H1][PARAGRAPH:0]v1.187[PARAGRAPH:2]Rhye's and Fall è un mod basato sulla mappa del mondo, che cerca di trasformare una partita per giocatore singolo in un simulatore realistico di storia della Terra. È il seguito di "Rhye's of Civilization", uno dei mod più popolari per Civilization III. [PARAGRAPH:2]Il mod ruota attorno all'ascesa e al declino delle civiltà storiche: non avranno tutte inizio nel medesimo istante, ma nella propria epoca. Il giocatore può scegliere un avvio in ritardo (lasciando che la partita evolva per conto proprio) o prendere subito il controllo di una delle prime civiltà e passare a un'altra in un secondo momento. Le civiltà cadranno per diversi motivi, tra cui guerre civili scatenate da instabilità interna, e attacchi dei barbari programmati.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ogni civiltà è estremamente diversa dalle altre, grazie ai poteri unici, le condizioni di vittoria uniche e una intelligenza artificiale che fonderà le città nella loro corretta ubicazione storica, con il loro vero nome.[PARAGRAPH:2]Tra le altre aggiunte ci sono le epidemie di peste, le ambasciate, i congressi mondiali nei quali scambiare le città, la diffusione dinamica delle risorse, e una nuova grafica per bandiere e terreno.[PARAGRAPH:2]Il file readme contiene ulteriori informazioni. Per ogni altro dubbio potete visitare il sito ufficiale (http://rhye.civfanatics.net), il forum degli sviluppatori (http://forums.civfanatics.com/forumdisplay.php?f=204) o la voce wiki (http://rhye.civfanatics.net/wiki/), che contiene utili consigli strategici.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Bienvenido a "Rhye's and Fall of Civilization"[\H1][PARAGRAPH:0]v1.187[PARAGRAPH:2]"Rhye's and Fall of Civilization" es un mod basado en un mapa del mundo que intenta hacer que la partida para un jugador sea una simulación realista de la historia de la Tierra. Es la secuela de "Rhye's of Civilization", uno de los mods más populares de Civilization III. [PARAGRAPH:2]El mod gira en torno al auge y caída históricos de las civilizaciones: no empezarán todas al mismo tiempo, sino en las fechas precisas. El jugador puede optar por un inicio tardío (si se espera a que el programa juegue por sí mismo) o tomar el control de una de las civilizaciones y cambiar posteriormente a otra. Las civilizaciones pueden caer por muchos factores, incluyendo las guerras civiles causadas por la inestabilidad interna y los ataques bárbaros programados en el script.[PARAGRAPH:2]Cada civilización se diferencia acusadamente de las demás gracias a los PU (poderes únicos), las condiciones UVH (condiciones únicas para la victoria histórica) y una IA propia que ubicará las ciudades en su emplazamiento histórico y les dará su nombre real.[PARAGRAPH:2]Otros añadidos incluyen apariciones de plagas, embajadas, congresos mundiales donde se intercambian ciudades, una propagación dinámica de los recursos y nuevos gráficos para las marcas y terrenos.[PARAGRAPH:2]En el documento "Readme (Léame)" se proporciona información más detallada. Para cualquier otra cuestión, visita la página oficial (http://rhye.civfanatics.net), el foro de desarrollo (http://forums.civfanatics.com/forumdisplay.php?f=204) o la wikiguía (http://rhye.civfanatics.net/wiki/), que contiene consejos útiles sobre la estrategia.

TEXT.English: [H1]The Great Christian Schism[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Similar to Protestantism, Orthodoxy is founded by a special event instead of only discovering a certain technology. In this case it is the Great Schism, which is triggered by building the Apostolic Palace. This represents the beginning of the tradition of the Catholic Papacy and the subsequent theological differences to the Eastern Christian churches, which manifest as the Orthodox faith in the game. That means that the civilization that builds the Apostolic Palace will not found Orthodoxy, instead another civilization will be chosen according to their historical relation to the Orthodox faith. Subsequently, other civilizations will convert to Orthodoxy depending on how far to the west the founding civilization is situated. The player will be asked whether he wants to convert, however, if he was the original founder of Orthodoxy and decides not to convert, his holy city will not receive a free shrine.

[H1]Slavery[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Dawn of Civilization aims to represent the transatlantic slave trade as part of the Columbian Exchange. To this purpose, a slave unit has been added to the game.[NEWLINE][BOLD]Creating slave units[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Slaves cannot be trained like other units. Instead they can be created using the "enslave" button in the city screen, which takes the place of the draft button where it is available. This button is only available for civs that use the Slavery civic in cities that are situated in Sub-Saharan Africa and have a population of at least six. Like the draft action, enslaving costs one unit of population and three unhappiness, and creates a slave unit in this city.Slaves can also be acquired by defeating Impis and Pombos. If the battle took place on your territory and you are using Slavery, there is a chance that you will get a slave unit afterwards.Another alternative is purchasing slaves by trade from other civilizations, using the slave trade option of the diplomacy screen, which is explained below.[NEWLINE][BOLD]Trading slave units[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]It is possible to acquire slaves by trade, which allows civilizations that don't have access to cities in Africa to use slaves. Trade can be conducted through the usual diplomacy interface; if the civilization you are talking to has available slave units, they appear on their side of the negotiation table and can be bought just like any other item. The same is true for the units you own. If you have adopted the Egalitarianism civic, slave trade becomes unavailable to you. Civilizations place value on slaves depending on if they have a use for them, i.e. if they have colonies in the Americas or Africa. On the other hand, native African civilizations will not buy slaves.[NEWLINE][BOLD]Using slave units[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The use of slaves is limited by geographical region: they can only be used in the Americas, or in Sub-Saharan Africa unless the civilization has its capital there. Slaves can be used in the following ways:[NEWLINE][BOLD]Build a slave plantation:[\BOLD] the slave can build a slave plantation on all tiles that have a resource which requires a plantation, yielding +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] and +2 [ICON_COMMERCE] compared to a normal plantation. The slave is used in the process, similar to a work boat.[NEWLINE][BOLD]Join city as a slave specialist:[\BOLD] the slave can permanently join the city as a slave specialist, yielding 2 [ICON_PRODUCTION] and creating 1 [ICON_UNHAPPY]. The number of slaves per city is limited to half of its population.[NEWLINE][BOLD]Freeing the slaves[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Both uses of the slave unit (plantations and specialists) can only continue as long as you are not running the Egalitarianism civic. As soon as you adopt Egalitarianism, all slave plantations on your territory will revert to normal plantations, and all slave specialists in your cities will be lost permanently. When a civilization running Egalitarianism gains control of a slave plantation, the improvement reverts to a normal plantation. Slave specialists are always removed on city conquest. If the conquering civilization is running Egalitarianism, these slaves are lost permanently. Otherwise the conqueror receives an equal amount of slave units with the opportunity of settling them elsewhere.[PARAGRAPH]The adoption of Egalitarianism by other civilizations increases the amount of unhappiness created by slaves, creating a growing incentive to adopt Egalitarianism as well to combat the unhappiness from slavery.[NEWLINE][BOLD]The Aztecs[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The Aztec unique power enables them to acquire slave units by winning battles; regardless of the losing unit there is a chance of acquiring a slave unit. Aztec slaves also have the additional abilities of acting as workers and can be sacrificed in their cities, as a way to temporarily increase happiness there.

[H1]Stability Influence Factors[\H1] [NEWLINE][BOLD]EXPANSION[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Overextension[\BOLD] Overextension is the main factor of expansion stability. It depends on two scores: [ICON_BULLET]core population score [ICON_BULLET]periphery population score [NEWLINE]Without taking modifiers into account, they are just the population in your core and the population outside of your core, respectively. As long as your periphery population score is below your core population score, everything is fine. Once the periphery score exceeds 100% of the core population score, you will receive an expansion stability penalty according to a formula which I will explain later. The scores are affected by a number of modifiers and therefore aren't only based on city population. [NEWLINE]The [BOLD]core population score[\BOLD] is multiplied by your current era plus one. Since the modifier is era-based, your ability to support a large periphery grows during the game. [NEWLINE]The [BOLD]periphery population score[\BOLD] for every city is based on many different factors. Since a lower periphery score is better for stability, negative modifiers are desired. +2 if the city is not on historical territory (so it makes sense to mainly control historical tiles) +1 if you are not the original owner of this city (unless you are running Totalitarianism or Warrior Code, or the city is under your control for more than 25 turns) +1 if you have less than 50% culture in this city +1 if you have less than 20% culture in this city (those two penalties are cumulative, for a total of +2 if you are below 20%. Culture counts double within their civilization's own cores. Persia is immune to culture-based penalties due to their UP) +2 when running City States (this civic is only meant for small civilizations) +1 if it is a historical overseas city an you are running Totalitarianism (to discourage Totalitarianism for maintaining colonial empires) -1 if the city has a Courthouse -1 if the city has a Jail -1 if it is an overseas city and you are running Mercantilism -1 if it is an overseas city and you are Portugal (their UP) [NEWLINE]The expansion penalty can be at most -25, and grows faster right after the periphery score exceeds the core score than later on. This allows a diminishing yet growing effect of expansion stability that allows playing Domination games without making expansion stability irrelevant in more historical games. [NEWLINE]Between stability checks, the overextension penalty can only increase by at most 5 negative points. For instance, if you had a penalty of 0 in the last check and the calculation results in -10, you will still only get a penalty of -5 until the next check. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Razing[\BOLD] Razing cities is the other contributing factor to expansion stability. The score here is very straightforward. You get a -10 stability penalty for every city you have razed. This penalty decays by 2 points every 5 turns. This penalty is global, that means if you accrue -20 raze stability from razing two cities, it still decays by 2 points every 5 turns, instead of by 4. The exception to this rule are smaller cities. If the city has a population of less than 5, the penalty is -2 * [city population] instead. This exception does not apply to another civilizations capital, which always gives a -10 penalty when razed. [NEWLINE][BOLD]ECONOMY[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Economic Growth[\BOLD] The economic growth score is updated every third turn, in which the total amount of commerce produced is compared to the amount from three turns earlier. Has it grown by more than 5%, the score increases, has it shrunk by more than 5%, it decreases. Otherwise the score slowly moves towards 0 again. At every stability check the score is directly applied to the economy stability. Some of your civics influence your economic growth stability: [ICON_BULLET]you receive extra points during economic growth when running Free Market [ICON_BULLET]you receive no penalties during economic stagnation when running Environmentalism [ICON_BULLET]you receive less penalties during economic decline when running Public Welfare [NEWLINE][BOLD]Trade[\BOLD] Your cities have trade routes to other cities generating commerce (exports). Other cities have trade routes to your cities also generating commerce (imports). For all civilizations, their total trade volume is calculated, which usually is the sum of exports and imports, but for Mercantilist civs it is twice their export volume instead. The trade volume is divided by your number of cities, then subtracted a modifier that increases with your era. Effectively, you can achieve a positive score by increasing the trade yield in your cities and securing trade routes with foreign cities. The trade stability is capped at +10 and -10 respectively. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Economic Systems[\BOLD] Civilizations running Mercantilism receive a -2 penalty for having open borders with a civilization with a higher commerce output. Civilizations running Central Planning receive a -2 penalty for having open borders with a civilization that runs Free Market. [NEWLINE][BOLD]DOMESTIC[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Happiness[\BOLD] Happiness stability works similar to economic growth stability in that it is accumulating every third turn depending on the situation of your civilization. To that end, the happy and unhappy cities in a civilization are counted based on the following criteria: [NEWLINE][BOLD]Happy city:[\BOLD] currently celebrates the "We Love the King" day OR its happiness exceeds its unhappiness by at least a quarter of your empire's average city size and it has at least the average city size of your empire [BOLD]Unhappy city:[\BOLD] the city has more unhappiness than happiness OR the extra unhappiness (from all factors except population) exceeds a fifth of the city's population [NEWLINE]Note that it is possible for a city to not fulfill either of these criteria, in which case it doesn't count at all for the purposes of happiness stability. A city can also both fulfill the criteria for being happy and unhappy, in which case it counts as happy. Your happiness stability grows every third turn if you have more happy than unhappy cities, and declines if you have more unhappy than happy cities. This factor cannot exceed -10 or 10, respectively. If the amount of happy and unhappy cities is exactly the same, the value slowly approaches 0 again. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Religion[\BOLD] For religions, two or three percentages are calculated: [ICON_BULLET]the percentage of cities that have your state religion (believer ratio) [ICON_BULLET]the percentage of cities that have at least one non-state religion (heathen ratio) [ICON_BULLET]if you are running Theocracy, the percentage of cities that have ONLY your state religion [NEWLINE]Some non-state religions are ignored for the purposes of the second and third ratios ("tolerance"). [ICON_BULLET]civs with Secularism tolerate all non-state religions [ICON_BULLET]Mughals tolerate all non-state religions because of their UP [ICON_BULLET]Hinduism and Buddhism tolerate each other [ICON_BULLET]Confucianism and Taoism tolerate each other [NEWLINE][BOLD]Heathen ratio:[\BOLD] You incur neither penalties nor bonuses if your ratio is 30%. Otherwise, you receive -1 stability for every 10% over 30% and +1 stability for every 10% below 30%. [BOLD]Believer ratio:[\BOLD] You incur neither penalties nor bonuses if your ratio is 75%. Otherwise, you receive -1 stability for every 5% below 75% (up to a maximum of -10) and +1 stability for every 5% over 75%. [BOLD]Theocracy bonus:[\BOLD] if you are running Theocracy, you also receive +1 stability for every 20% of your cities that only have your state religion. [NEWLINE]Note that while the other factors require you to have a state religion, the religion stability from the heathen ratio also applies when you don't have a state religion. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Civics[\BOLD] Civics stability comes either from running a certain combination of civics or from running specific civics in a certain era or after discovering a certain technology.
Totalitarianism + Autocracy: +5 Totalitarianism + Central Planning: +3 Totalitarianism + [any religious civic except Secularism]: -5
Central Planning + Industrialism: +2 Central Planning + [any labor civic except Industrialism or Public Welfare]: -5
Egalitarianism + Republic: +2 Egalitarianism + [any labor civic except Public Welfare]: -3 Egalitarianism + Environmentalism: +2 Egalitarianism + Secularism: +2
Capitalism + Representation: +2 Capitalism + Free Market: +3 Capitalism + Guilds: -5
Environmentalism + Industrialism: -5

Vassalage + Levy Armies: +3 Vassalage + [any other military civic]: -5 Vassalage + Capitalism or Industrialism or Public Welfare: -5 Vassalage + Dynasticism: +2 in the Middle Ages Vassalage + Agrarianism: +3 in the Middle Ages
City States + Vassalage or Absolutism or Egalitarianism: -3 City States + Guilds: +2 City States + Free Market, Central Planning, or Environmentalism: -5 City States + Militia or Mercenaries: +2 City States + [any military civic except Militia, Mercenaries and Naval Dominance]: -3
Absolutism + Republic: -5 Absolutism + Mercantilism: +3 Absolutism + Organized Religion: +2 Absolutism + Dynasticism: +2 in the Renaissance
Republic + Representation: +2
Autocracy + Standing Army: +3
Multilateralism + Autocracy: -2 Multilateralism + Totalitarianism: -3 Multilateralism + Fanaticism: -3 Multilateralism + Egalitarianism: +2
Vassalage in the Middle Ages: +2 Vassalage in the Industrial Era or later: -5
Theocracy in the Industrial Era or later: -5

City States in the Classical Era or earlier: +2 City States in the Industrial Era or later: -5

Any Organization civic except Totalitarianism and Egalitarianism after the discovery of Communism: -5

Mercenaries after the discovery of Nationalism: -5 [NEWLINE][BOLD]FOREIGN[\BOLD] [NEWLINE]A couple of factors contribute to your foreign stability rating:
For every neighboring collapsing civ that you have open borders with: -3
For every collapsing vassal: -5 For every unstable vassal: -2 For every solid vassal: +3 For every vassal when running Vassalage: +2
For every defensive pact with a higher ranked civilization: +5 For every defensive pact with another civilization while running Multilateralism: +3
For every open borders treaty with a civ with your state religion: +1 For every open borders treaty with a civ with a different state religion: +2 For every second civilization you can contact: -1

For every neighbor you are at war with while running Autocracy: +2 For every civilization you are at war with while running Multilateralism: -2 For every civilization with different state religion you are at war with while running Fanaticism: +3 For every civilization with the same state religion you are at war with while running Fanaticism: -2 [NEWLINE][BOLD]MILITARY[\BOLD] [NEWLINE]All military scores are calculated for each war your civilization is in. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Conquest Stability[\BOLD] This factor depends on the number of cities you have conquered from this civ compared to those you have lost to it. Cities are worth more if the owner has less of them, i.e. losing a city has a larger impact if you don't have a lot of them in the first place. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Battle Stability[\BOLD] Similar to conquest stability, the battles you have won are compared to the battles you have lost. In either case, a battle is "worth" as much as the defeated unit's power rating. How much battle stability you get or lose depends on your overall military strength - the stronger you are, the less of an impact a singular battle has in either way. Battle stability decays while a war lasts. [NEWLINE][BOLD]War Weariness Stability[\BOLD] Your war weariness is compared to your enemy's. If it is larger, you receive a penalty proportional to the difference. This penalty also decays while the war lasts. [NEWLINE][BOLD]Barbarian Losses Stability[\BOLD] You receive a -1 stability penalty for every battle you lose against a barbarian unit. This penalty also decays over time.
